On the morning the monkeys learned how to make a siren out of a traffic cone, Ephraim Cole counted twenty-seven of them on the tram. The driver didn’t stop them; the driver never stopped them anymore. A capuchin with a bandaged ear dangled from the rubber strap above Ephraim’s head and spit a single sunflower seed onto the calculus text of a high school girl. The capuchin kept one eye on Ephraim’s briefcase. They all did that now, like the case might open and exhale a roast chicken or a grenade.

“Morning, pen-chewer,” the bandaged one said, voice like a pipe scraped by a wire. He had learned Ephraim’s face two months ago, after the audit board forced the City to publish the monkey tickets and fines; it was still strange to be famous to the wrong species.

“Good morning,” Ephraim said, because he never could carve a new habit for himself. Courtesy had calcified around him into a shape like a second skin, the shape of a compliant man in a tilted city.

“Drop that box,” the monkey said, then laughed and clapped at its own joke like a cymbalist. “You drop it, we catch it, you cry.”

“I won’t drop it,” Ephraim said. The girl with the calculus text lifted her book and wiped the sunflower seed away. The driver let the tram sigh through an intersection where four macaques in orange construction vests waved plastic paddles and made obscene faces at the buses. One of the vest monkeys had a whistle; he alternated between a regulation no-noise and a ululated wolf-cry that made the pigeons on the wires throw themselves into the morning like a blanket tossed off a bed.

Ephraim was forty-seven years old, unmarried, with a mortgage he despised and a sister who still loved him in a way that flummoxed him. He kept his hair short because monkeys pulled hair when they were angry. He had a precise face, a precise way of walking, and a precise belief that numbers were bones and we could look through them to see the body that had walked there before. He worked at Kettle & Hart, a firm known for making the ungovernable governable until the monkeys moved in and declared governance a snack.

As the tram eased into St. Alabaster’s Square, a troop of vervets jogged alongside, their tails flying like banners. One—smaller, with a burn scar like a coin on its shoulder—threw a handful of gravel at the windows. “Audit this!” the small one shouted, and then, in falsetto, “We appreciate your service!” The others cackled and slapped one another’s back as if applause could be traded. The bandaged capuchin tugged at the strap until the rubber groaned.

“You’re late,” it said. “You’re late, numbers, numbers, numbers. Where’s your tail? I have one.” It twitched its little hook to demonstrate.

“I’m not late,” Ephraim said, although he was ten minutes behind, and he hated himself for the need to correct the statement. “And I don’t chew pens.”

“Oh? You chew little boys?” Another cymbal-clap. A murmur from the humans in the car. Ephraim’s briefcase weighed a mile. The capuchin stuck its tongue out, pale and repulsive and weirdly human at the edges. “Little boy uncle. Uncle eats, uncle eats.”

“Stop,” the girl with the textbook said. Her voice had that end-of-argument tone certain teenagers carry like an extra rib. “You’re disgusting.”

“We’re art,” the monkey said, and slid back out the open window as the tram doors peeled open. It was gone into the chrome and sun and diesel.

On the platform, a troupe of monkeys had stacked crates and were attempting to stand on each other’s shoulders to reach a banner that read MONKEYS FOR SENSEFUL STREETS. The sign had been paid for by the Chamber of Commerce as a friendly show of support. Last week’s Chamber president resigned with a rash. The crates trembled. A rhesus monkey at the bottom groaned and barfed onto the pavement. The one above him laughed, poked the vomit with a pencil, and wrote something obscene with it that looked, somehow, a little like Ephraim’s name.

Familiar gooseflesh climbed Ephraim’s arms as he considered turning back for home, for the toasted rye he had left on the counter and the dome of quiet around his apartment above the bakery. But he had an appointment. And also—though he hardly said it even to himself—it felt like quitting when people were watching. He kept moving, kept his briefcase tucked under his elbow like a heart he didn’t want to hand back.

Kettle & Hart occupied the tenth and eleventh floors of the Gray Tower, although “occupied” was inaccurate: somewhere between city policy and monkey preference, the tenth floor had become a playground. No one could think why. The monkeys didn’t work there; they didn’t sleep there. They only hung from the fluorescent light fixtures and yowled in tight harmonies that made interns cry. They dipped their paws in the fish tank and threw guppies at the arrow plants. Someone had brought a swing—someone had affixed the swing to the load-bearing crossbeam. It creaked. The building inspectors signaled a complaint, but the complaint was caught and chewed on by a gang of spider monkeys who ate vowels like potato chips.

“Morning, Mr. Cole,” said Darla, the receptionist, as he stepped off the elevator into the lobby on eleven. She was dressed in a blouse the color of clean money, the exact tint of cash that hadn’t thought about itself enough to be dirty.

“Morning,” he said. He glanced at the glass—monkeys’ faces were smeared into the lobby windows like thumbprints on a mirror. One made a heart with its hands when he looked. Another threw a rock.

Darla slid him a folder across the counter. “The mayor’s office called. Your methods are ‘too revealing’? They’d like you to use fewer colors.” Her mouth didn’t change shape as she said it.

He opened the folder. Inside there was a memo with the City seal and the subheading Suggestions for Softer Accounting. He had invented those color graphs because they were the only way to make the river of money look like a river. He had been told repeatedly that citizens liked rivers; rivers were calming. His graphs showed the City’s main channels and the tributaries: a blue torrent down the middle, a green stream for parks, a brown trickle that oozed toward rat control. And off to one side, a new canal that had opened in October, labeled Public Simian Integration Fund. It was a bright yellow that flickered as if someone had set the room on fire.

“Fewer colors,” Ephraim said. He looked up. “We’re bleeding yellow.”

“I’m not supposed to say that,” Darla said. “You’re not supposed to say anything that sounds like that.” She leaned closer. A monkey pressed its face to the glass, cheeks flat, breath spooling a fog. “You remember you’re having lunch with Miriam and Rory.”

“How could I forget,” he said, and instantly felt the guilt that followed repeated tenderness. He liked lunch with his sister. He liked the way his nephew stole the olives. He liked the way the olives looked, too—little green eyeballs in their dish, wet and ridiculous.

He made it to his office with only one interruption, a small troop of monkeys who had discovered his door and had written on it in grease pencil: FRIED ACCOUNTANT. They had drawn a crude pan. He wiped the drawing away with the sleeve of his jacket and made a mental note to stop making mental notes. It was exhausting to owe himself so much.

He loved his office still: the parquet floor stared back at him with quiet pattern; the books smelled like paper instead of panic. He opened his laptop and typed his password: abacus462!—a gentle insult to himself—and the spreadsheet bloomed like a forewarned flower.

Six months of figures. Ticketing revenue down. Banana import tax up. Gasoline spent on chases involving motorcycle-riding macaques: up, up, uP. A curious line item from the Department of Cultural Affairs called Interprimatic Reparations: ongoing. He drilled into it. Contractor names. A nonprofit named Bright Bridges run out of an address that didn’t exist: 999 Cherry Road. A series of five payments to something called Uncle’s Tithe Fund. He made a fist in the air like a conductor with no orchestra. He breathed. He looked. The column said the payments had been listed not as expenses but as swaps. Assets for assets. City for time.

He called up the PDF of the original agreement that had been signed in that televised ceremony in the courthouse rotunda, the one where a female mandrill in a satin jacket had licked the microphone and the mayor had laughed like a man falling through a glass table. Reconciliation Accord, the document said. He typed a search for “tithe.” Nothing. But the ledger kept the unsayable like a smuggled spoon.

“Cole,” said a voice from his doorway. He turned. Mr. Hart himself leaned there like a rakish uncle in a play, a tie dangling, a grin that had browned like a banana. He was a good man in the way that a boat can be good in a storm and useless in dock.

“Good morning,” Ephraim said.

“Color trouble,” Hart said, and whistled through his teeth. “Don’t soften for them. Not yet.” He stepped into the office, hip bumped a plant, didn’t notice. “Going to the museum tonight?”

“What museum.”

“Countinghouse Museum? Lark’s talk. ‘Numerics in the Age of Primate Civility.’ He’s going to say something he shouldn’t. He hinted. He can’t stop hinting, that man. I figure someone has to clap loudly.” Hart peered at the screen. He hummed a C. “Uncle’s Tithe Fund. That’s new.”

“You’ve seen it?”

“I’ve seen everything,” Hart said, then spread his hands. “But I don’t know how to see this. There’s a rumor the monkeys want to make the uncle the new father.”

“What?”

Hart inclined his head. “It doesn’t make sense, Cole. You’re right. This whole thing is cross-eyed. But—” He stopped, glanced out the glass wall toward the monkeys who had found their reflections and were making love to them. “Everything makes sense to someone.”

“I don’t like that someone,” Ephraim said. “I don’t like that he’s in my spreadsheet.”

Hart laughed. “Lunch with Miriam?” He had a way of asking questions he already knew the answers to that made you forgive him for asking.

“I’m going,” Ephraim said.

“Good. Eat good food. It might get scarce when the scooters run out of gas.” Hart’s face twitched. “If the monkeys start siphoning fuel, it’s all over.”

“They don’t need fuel,” Ephraim said. “They need an audience.”

“Amen,” Hart said. He clapped him on the shoulder and left a faint hair on his sleeve. Ephraim plucked it off as if it might deliver a surprise stinger.

He worked an hour. He took notes. He made a small chart with fewer colors—a grayscale puddle that told the truth with a whisper. He printed it and slid it into a manila folder and wrote in block letters: TRUTH BUT QUIET. He shut his laptop. He touched his forehead to the cool glass and watched a juvenile monkey investigate a stapler like a bomb. The city had felt like this before, he thought, once long ago when he had been a boy and his mother had taught him to add his change at the grocery store. That was the day he’d realized that sometimes the numbers came up wrong because someone had taken something. He had been seven; he had cried. His mother had looked around and said, “Shh. Not so loud. There are other kinds of wrong to worry about.”

At twenty to twelve he walked to Café Hav, where the tables on the sidewalk had been fitted with spring-loaded lids to discourage theft. The lids did nothing but make the compliments louder when they worked. Miriam was already there, hair tucked into a scarf, hands wrapped around a glass of water like it was a small animal she meant to teach a trick. He loved her forehead most: the wide plain of it, the place where she stored her thoughts. Her son—his nephew—Rory—sat opposite, chin in hand, the other hand flicking through videos on his phone. He had dyed his hair a shade of blue that wasn’t a color but a refusal. He looked up, saw Ephraim, and managed a smile that felt like an eclipse: a bright circle borrowed from the dark.

“You’re late,” Miriam said, and then kissed his cheek. “I’ve ordered olives. We have a window of time.”

“Before what?” Ephraim asked.

“Before they remember they like them,” she said. She nodded toward a pair of monkeys crouching on the fire escape above, smoking cigarettes they had stolen from the bus depot. The cigarettes made them cough; the coughing made them laugh. Everything that hurt made them louder.

“Hi, Uncle E,” Rory said. “I took a video of a gibbon putting Mayor Henley’s hat in a urinal. It’s art.”

“You sound like them,” Ephraim said, and immediately regretted it.

“Not like them,” Rory said softly. He flicked through his phone. “They’re dirty poets.” He lifted the device so Ephraim could see: there was the mayor, face spanked with sweat, looking up as a long-limbed gray creature lowered the hat into a bowl that had not been cleaned since the last three parades.

“They learned it from us,” Miriam said. “They learn everything from us. That’s the problem—it’s all a mirror. I just wish the mirror was clean.”

Ephraim sat. The waiter brought olives, a plate of fried anchovies, and bread with a rind like a crusted planet. They ate first—always eat first, Miriam had taught him—because conversation could be stolen but food could only be taken from you one bite at a time, and that took time.

“How’s school,” he asked Rory, so he could pretend the world was normal. “Any good teachers.”

“Mr. Lark is my favorite,” Rory said.

“The museum one?” Ephraim asked.

“Adjunct,” Rory said with the sadness of someone who had learned too soon how words could make a ladder and also a cage. “He’s teaching a class on Counting Rituals. He says before we wrote numbers we had to eat a number.”

“Eat a number,” Miriam said. “I love that nonsense.”

“It’s not nonsense,” Rory said, and looked at Ephraim for allyhood. “He says you can’t hold a thing you don’t recognize. You have to put it in your mouth to know it. Infants. Tribes. Banks.” He tore a piece of bread and ate it, eyes closed. “He says there was a ceremony, very old, where the man who kept the ledger, to inoculate the village against loss, had to—” He stopped, looked at his mother, and then said quickly, “It’s a silly story.”

“Tell it,” Miriam said, mouth full.

“He had to eat his kin,” Rory said.

Ephraim’s fork paused midair. He set it down. “Which kin.”

“Nephew,” Rory said. He didn’t smile. He didn’t look up. “It’s stupid. It was a metaphor. Mr. Lark loves metaphors. He’s like a metaphor with tenure.”

“Adjuncts don’t have tenure,” Miriam said. “Also don’t say nephew. It tastes strange.”

“It tasted strange in class too,” Rory said, and then he looked at his uncle, really looked, as if looking was a new thing one might try between mouthfuls of fish. “You okay?”

“I’m fine,” Ephraim said. “It’s a story. We have a stack of them. The monkeys like to climb them.”

Rory laughed. Miriam rolled an olive across the table to him. He caught it with a hand he didn’t know he trusted yet. Ephraim felt something cold drift through him like a cloud across a field, a shadow with a square edge. He drank water.

“It’s not your job to fix the city,” Miriam said later, when they were waiting for coffee. “You hear me? We all have two hands. If you spend both on the wheel, you don’t have any left to drink your coffee.”

“You know there’s a tithe,” he said, because the word had been rattling around his ribs since he’d seen it. “In the records. An Uncle’s Tithe.”

Miriam’s eyes narrowed. She was good at narrowing. “That’s a knot I don’t want to pick. Let’s eat our pastries.”

They did. The coffee was a little bitter, in the way things are bitter when you want them to be sweet. A young macaque across the street tried to steal the salt shaker from the table of an elderly man; when the old man moved to block, the macaque bit his knuckle and then put its hand to its mouth and made exaggerated gagging faces as if he had fed it poison. Two other monkeys imitated the gag. They laughed. The old man stared at his hand like it had turned into a piece of the moon. He stowed it in his lap and would not take it out again.

Ephraim walked back to the office through a gaggle of them. One looked at his shoes and said, “Nice feet, uncle.” Another threw him a puck of chewed gum, pink and wet. The world smelled like exhaust and old fruit. He missed the smell of snow, the way it had used to smell when he was young and the world had stopped for a minute and then started again with good intentions.

When he sat again, he’d been gone two hours. Two new messages: one from the mayor’s assistant, explaining how color had feelings; one from the Countinghouse Museum, a bland invitation to Lark’s talk with a line at the bottom that had been pasted in crooked: bring a friend or bring none. We are happy with your choice. The font was wrong. When he printed it, the letters flickered as if heat were rising off them.

At five he went. He told Darla he’d bring her back a pin from the museum shop. She told him to bring her back a piece of good news, and then made the sign against the evil eye her grandmother had given her for free. The monkeys followed him for six blocks, hooting and making little kissing sounds, and then peeled off at the intersection where an ice cream truck had learned that playing calliope music would now be answered with rocks.

Countinghouse stood with its back to the river, a square building with a frieze of coins around the top. The glass doors were scummed with monkey prints. Inside, the guards had been given whistles, and when a macaque tried to slide in on a local boy’s heels, the guards blew so hard their cheeks fluttered like flags. The macaque laughed and mimed blowing into an invisible whistle until a third guard kissed him on the head, which somehow worked and the macaque left.

“Mr. Cole,” said a voice. Professor Lark materialized like a thesis from behind a column. Thin as a line, hair that had lost interest in obeying gravity, a tie printed with little numbers at play. “I’m sorry about the tram. It’s a chorus these days.”

“I had sardines for lunch,” Ephraim said, a bit too quickly. “What’s a tithe.”

Lark blinked. “You didn’t say hello.”

“I said it in my heart. What’s a tithe.”

Lark’s mouth twisted. “A little bit of sacrifice formalized into the ledger so that you can look at it without bleeding.”

“So you bleed and then you record it,” Ephraim said.

“You record it and therefore you can bleed,” Lark said, not unkindly. “Come inside. I will tell you something during the Q&A that will make three donors leave. I can’t help it.”

They stood through Lark’s talk with fifty other citizens—fewer than before, Ephraim noted, although more than an English department reading. The monkey presence was there, too: small furry shapes on rafters, a hand dipping into a purse, a whispered slur like a draught in winter. Lark spoke about the earliest tallies, about knotted cords and burnt marks on bone. He showed an image of a ledger from a village nobody wanted to admit they came from, a book that had been kept under a floorboard in a hut that had been moved from the valley to a living room to a display.

“The book doesn’t say it,” Lark said, and the lights deepened around his body. “The book doesn’t write the part that makes you sick. The book keeps you from throwing up. It says grain. It says wheat. It says goats. It says winter. It says aunt. It says tree. It says nephew.” He paused. He was dramatic. He didn’t need props. “But the elders did not do what we do with the nephew. They didn’t make him a scholarship. They didn’t give him to marriage. They—” His mouth did a little grieving thing. He shook his head.

Someone in the back said, as a joke, “They ate him,” and the room rippled. You could almost see the ripple, like heat.

Lark swallowed. “It was not a feast,” he said. “It was a counting. It was not cruelty, in the sense that a cat is cruel to a bird. It was algebra. A thing you hope not to have to do again.”

A monkey from the rafters blew him a kiss and then made a rude suggestion with its finger. Lark bowed toward it, still scholarly. “The world bears the marks of our arithmetic,” he said. “When the sums go mad, the animals correct us.” His eyes found Ephraim’s like a pin into a butterfly. “We thought we could live without a ledger. But we cannot live without the person who holds the ledger.”

On his way down the museum steps, someone pressed a paper into Ephraim’s hand. He didn’t see the face. The paper crackled like something that had been dried on a radiator. He stuck it into his jacket pocket because his first instinct, after being handed something he didn’t understand, was not to understand it yet. He walked along the river. He looked down into the water and thought of tongues. If you put a number into your mouth, would you learn it? If you put a world?

When he got home—climb the stairs, key stuck in a stubborn lock, the smell of baking sunk into the wood like forgiveness—he took the paper out and unfolded it and saw seven lines of writing in a hand so careful it could have been a mask.

Ephraim Cole. You are the appointed. You will do the killing that saves. The monkeys will jeer. The people will weep. The balance will tilt back away from the bright snow. Eat the boy you love. Eat him before the Harvest Moon. Or all of us will be eaten by the final winter. Please do it clean.

He sat. He put the paper on the table and put a glass of water on top of it as if it might float away. He went to the sink and washed his hands. He washed them until the monkeys outside began to bang on the fire escape and chant, in a nursery rhythm that had kept him company for the last two months: “Uncle’s belly, uncle’s belly, yum yum yum.”

Someone, he thought, was playing with him. He had always been easy to play with; he had had the wrong face for ignoring.

He tore the note in half and then into quarters and then into something like lint. He opened the window and saw the troop on the fire escape. They wore curtains like capes; one smoked a cigarette with the wrong end in its mouth and acted out choking for the others who applauded. “Boo,” said the smallest. “Boo uncle.”

“Go away,” he said, so mild, so mild it made him angry. He shut the window.

He slept badly. Dreams like spreadsheets, cells’ edges cutting into him. He woke at three and there it was again, the idea, the bright and awful clear idea like a sign on a bridge: this is where the road ends. It was stupid, it was offensive, it was impossible. It was also very simple. He hated simple. People used simple like a weapon.

At six, without coffee, he walked the three blocks to Miriam’s. The street was nearly quiet; only a few monkeys out, the early ones, smoking and spitting, scratching their bellies, tossing glass bottles in soft underhand arcs at shop doors. Miriam’s building was patched brick with a climbing vine that the monkeys had used to practice tying knots. He rang. He waited. He rang again. He could hear the radio inside, a voice that read the news with healthy confusion. He could feel the city stretching and then going stiff again in the cold.

“Eph?” Miriam’s voice at the door crack, and then the chain; then her face, hair messy, robe tied in a knot like a coin. “What’s wrong.” It wasn’t a question.

“Nothing,” he said. “I brought pastries. From the shop below my place.”

“You’re a devil,” she said. “Rory’s asleep. He came home late from a screening. Something called A Poem Made of Garbage.”

“I’ve heard of it,” he said, and he had, Rory had told him, and he hadn’t understood. You could see a poem and not understand it. You could eat one and fail to taste it. He had done both.

He sat in their kitchen, which had a table he had swaggered into their life with, a table he had rescued from the curb when a contractor had gone bankrupt and had left furniture in the street like a trail of bones. He liked the table because it could hold weight without telling you about it. Miriam poured coffee. They ate the pastries. The ones with cream had been flattened by the bag; cream oozed slightly out and they used their finger to wipe it up. He thought about tongues again. He thought about numbers. He thought about the way his throat closed.

“What’s the sound of bad news,” Miriam asked, and because they were siblings he said, “Shoes,” and they both laughed. That was what their mother had said the year the factory shut down, when the neighbors filled their SUVs with things they had worked on for half their lives. “Bad news sounds like shoes.” The clatter on the steps, the clatter backwards.

“I have a note,” he said. He didn’t know he was going to say it until it stood in the air between them. “In my pocket. Someone left it at the museum.”

“Do I want to hear it,” she asked.

“No,” he said. “But also you do.” He left the part out about how he had ripped it, and the part about how ripping had done nothing to it. He told her what it said. He told her the words like they had been written on a blackboard behind his eyes. He told her slowly, like the person you love is a fire that you can burn if you go too quickly.

Miriam pressed her thumb hard into the table. He saw the whitish oval where the blood moved away. She was quiet a long time. The radio talked about the monkeys. The radio talked about a ward in the south where a troop had taken over the elementary school and had refused to let the children leave until they had taught the monkeys how to spell filth. The radio used the word unfortunate. The radio said, “Authorities are urging calm,” and then a loud crash, as someone threw something at the radio.

“I hate this story,” Miriam said. “If you told me a different one, I would follow you into it. I would. I would wear whatever costume you told me to. But I can’t. I won’t. Two hundred years ago people did a lot of dirty things and they called it math. The world doesn’t ask you to be a knife.”

“It feels like the world does,” he said. “It has the tone.”

“What are we, then,” she asked, “if not the ones who tilt back? If not the ones who refuse to look at a boy and see an answer.”

He rubbed his face. He wanted to leave so he could stop hurting her with himself. He wanted to stay so whatever came would come while he was there to stand in front of it with his hair and his body and his poor math.

From Rory’s room came a crash. Then a curse. Then silence. Ephraim stood before Miriam could. He had a key to the hallway lock; he didn’t knock. He walked in like family walks in: with his hand up as if a room can be covered like a bird.

Rory sat cross-legged on the floor, surrounded by the spilled guts of his backpack: a camera, two notebooks, a banana with a bite out of it and then another bite out of the peel. He looked up, startled, then laughed, then saw his mother behind Ephraim and reconfigured his face. Ephraim wanted to call the face “honest,” but it was more complicated than that. It was what you put on when you knew the world wanted to suck on your skin.

“What broke,” Miriam asked. Her voice had gone into the tone she saved for nurses and that one uncle who drank the Christmas cards.

“The little tripod,” Rory said. “It was cheap. I bought it with my own money. It’s okay. I’ll use books instead.” He stacked some books. They were about film and about old cities and about how to make a home out of a place that bites.

Ephraim kneeled and set the tripod up and clicked it. It clicked. “A screw,” he said. “Not a break.” He turned the screw with his thumbnail until it obeyed. He wanted to fix everything with thumbnails and not with old words. He wanted to be allowed to do that.

“Thanks,” Rory said. He looked at him as if the thanks were a way to put a coin in a machine. “What’s wrong,” he asked, surprising both of them. “You look like math.”

“I am math,” Ephraim said, because it was easier than saying the other thing. “We’re going to go. I’ll send you that grant link, okay?”

Rory’s eyebrows lifted. “Don’t,” he said softly. “I will apply. But don’t give me a ladder that goes into the wrong house.”

On the way out, Miriam put her hand on Ephraim’s wrist. “We make our own sums,” she said. “We do. No one gets to tell us who is food.”

“I agree,” he said. The words floated like balloons; he tied them to his chair in his mind. “I agree.”

He went to work. He stared at his screen until seven. He solved for x and then for y. He solved for z and then he solved for a little boy with blue hair and a camera and a mother who was not wrong. He did not find a solution that did not put blood in the margins. The monkeys on the other side of the glass had taken to hitting their heads on the window in a steady rhythm. Someone had given them helmets. He did not decide anything because deciding would change the world and he was not ready to end the world yet. The world liked to decide itself.

On the tram home, the bandaged capuchin winked at him and made a motion like cutting a steak. “You do it yet?” it asked.

“Do what,” Ephraim said. His mouth was dry. He didn’t like its interest. He didn’t like the way news traveled in fur.

“Dinner,” the monkey said. “The city is hungry. Your stomach is a balcony.”

“Stop talking,” said the girl with the calculus book, and the monkey hopped away, offended but pleased with its own offended. The tram sang that song metal sings when it’s tired. The driver didn’t stop at the hospital even when a woman in the aisle clutched her belly and made a sound like a zipper breaking. They said the hospitals were full of monkeys. They said monkeys cradled babies and did not drop them. They said many things. Ephraim had learned, in the last six months, to write the words they say in his notebook and put a box beside them and leave it unchecked.

He got home at nine. The bakery downstairs had closed. The scent of sugar lingered like a rumor. He leaned against the door and thought about the moment before a storm when the air feels like a wet map, the moment where all the roads lead into the center and also away. He closed his eyes. He saw the word nephew. He saw it without letters. He saw it as a shape: a small shape with too much gravity, a shape that makes everything bend.

He opened his eyes. There was a second note under the door. He did not move. He watched it as if you could make a letter go away by not touching it. His heart did something he didn’t approve of. He bent finally, because that is what men who hold ledgers do, they bend and they lift and they add. He opened the note. He did not breathe while he opened it, as if oxygen were a vote.

It said: Do not share this with anyone. Do not. There is a timeline and we are already late. The monkeys are rehearsal. The bright snow is real. We will all die in it. Eat him, Ephraim. You said you would once. Once you said, If the world asked me, I would. The world is asking. It has written it on its cheek in lipstick. Do the small cruelty to prevent the large. Do the close harm to save the far.

No signature. A smear of something at the bottom that looked like ash but smelled like sugar.

He went to the window. Outside, a troop had stolen a car and were taking turns honking the horn while one sat on the roof and made a speech about freedom that was only curse words and two big ideas. A policeman stood on the corner and watched and smoked and didn’t call it in. A stranger walked past with a guitar case and did not open it. The world had learned how to keep its secrets in plain sight.

He slept on the couch because the bed was haunted by decision. He woke at two to a sound that sounded like monkeys singing a lullaby and a man screaming his own name. He thought about the bright snow—ash, he supposed, an event where burning went wrong—and he looked at the ceiling and tried to make himself into the kind of person who could lift a fork with the wrong thing on it. He failed. He fell asleep imagining he had hung his conscience out the window like laundry, and the monkeys had stolen it, and were throwing it like a frisbee from one building to the other, and he was laughing in a way he never laughed.

Days snowed into one another like paperwork left outside. Lark sent him an email with a link to an article about ancient accountants with knives. Darla told him that a monkey had broken into the copy room and eaten a ream of paper with a relish that had made the interns almost love it. Hart canceled a meeting and rescheduled it and canceled it again. The mayor was on television saying that a little anarchy was just the price of life. Miriam texted him a picture of Rory asleep, face half turned, the blue hair like a lake in winter. He stared at the picture for a long time. He hit the heart. He put the phone on the table and did not pick it up again for a while.

Then the first fire came. It was small and stupid. A macaque playing with a bottle of rubbing alcohol in a barber shop. A match, a flare, a whoop. The hair-curled smoke. The barbers went outside. The monkeys clapped. Someone threw a bucket of water that was not enough. The newspaper ran a picture that was almost beautiful, and in the corner of the picture, a man who looked like Ephraim watched a ceiling tile fall, and you could see his hand had lifted slightly, as if a reflex might catch a burning square of artificial sky, as if catching were a promise. The caption read: Barber Fire One of Many Small Incidents. The paper liked to end sentences with a verb. It told you nothing was finished.

At Kettle & Hart, Ephraim’s spreadsheet grew a new column: costs of burns, costs of smoke, costs of night. He colored it black. He sent it to the mayor. The mayor’s assistant wrote back a string of emojis the meaning of which was: send fewer graphs and also die.

On Thursday afternoon, Lark came into his office without knocking and shut the door and cried. He cried with his whole body, like he had been holding something an hour too long. Ephraim stood up and did the thing most people would do, which is put a hand tentatively on someone else’s back and then leave their hand there, a hand as placeholder for all the things you cannot do.

“They told me,” Lark said into the crook of his elbow. “There is an item. A budget. There’s a date. It’s printed. Someone printed it. If you print it, it becomes real. You know that.”

“What is the item,” Ephraim asked, though he knew the tune.

“Uncle’s Tithe,” Lark said. “It’s not metaphor anymore. It’s an appointment.” He laughed, a broken cup sound. “They wrote in the cost: none.” He looked up. His face was wet without shame. “Are we the kind of people who let an appointment keep itself?”

“Apparently,” Ephraim said. “Apparently we are walking toward it like a dentist appointment.”

“You could refuse,” Lark said. “You could. You could go on television. You could be arrested. It’s a kind of math. You could put yourself in prison instead. If they take you, they can’t make you.”

“That feels like a small math,” Ephraim said, though he didn’t know. He didn’t know anything larger. “It feels like a math where you save your name.”

“My name is already gone,” Lark said. “The monkeys say it wrong on purpose. People clap.” He swiped his face dry. He pressed his hands to the top of Ephraim’s desk. “Don’t do it. Don’t be the ledger they want.”

“I don’t want to be,” Ephraim said, and saw that that sentence meant nothing.

He walked home in a wind that had learned new directions. The sky had a color like cold meat. He stopped beneath a traffic light where a macaque in a baseball cap was pretending to be a police officer and waving cars through red lights. A man in a van blew through and a taxi struck him and the monkeys laughed until one of them fell off the streetlight and sprained its wrist and then they laughed again. No one came. A woman on the corner shouted at nobody that she was leaving, that she would leave now, then stopped shouting and sat on a box like sitting was a death she could manage.

At his door there was a third note. He did not have to read it to hear it. He put it in the drawer with the other fragments. He made himself an omelet with too much salt. He could not bring himself to eat it. He ate a piece of toast instead. He threw the omelet away and felt like a criminal. If everything ends, he thought, it will end like this: the trash full of good eggs, the monkeys on the fire escape howling little hymns. He went to sleep in his bed because the couch had learned his fear and was feeding it back to him.

He dreamed that he was in a room with a long table and numbers in chairs. Each number had a napkin tucked into its collar. The number 7 turned to him and said, “We eat to live,” and the number 1 lifted a knife, and a 0 rolled itself to the door like a tire trying to escape.

In the morning he had decided not to decide until he had to. He wrote himself a note: procrastination is sometimes compassion. He taped it above his kettle. He went to work. The monkeys had taken the copy machine apart. They handed out pieces to passersby: a spring for you, a little glass for you, a broken tray for the old woman with the hat that looked like a chicken. Darla made a sound under her breath and then smiled. “We have no copier,” she said, as if confession were a new way to be clean.

At noon he went to the bathroom and splashed water on his face. He stared into the mirror. Behind him, a monkey was on the sink, pushing the soap dispenser like it was a casino lever. “It’s coming,” the monkey said cheerfully, in a voice it ought not to have had. “It’s on the calendar.”

“I know,” Ephraim said.

“Big dinner,” the monkey said. “Dessert? No. Boo. Eat first. Don’t talk.”

“Please stop,” Ephraim said, and turned and elbowed the monkey gently, and the monkey licked his elbow and then jumped to the floor and went under the stall and disappeared like a rumor that chose another city to live in.

He had an appointment in the afternoon with a woman from the Department of Cultural Affairs who smelled like a candle. She told him the Civic Theater was going to mount a production of a play called The Last Uncle. “It’s brave,” she said. “It’s about complicity.”

“That word,” he said, “that word will be the end of me.”

She laughed, and then she didn’t. “Do you have a nephew,” she asked with an innocence he knew was not entirely feigned. He stared at her until her face did a human thing that made him want to forgive her. He nodded. He didn’t say his name. Rory had not asked to be in a conversation with this woman.

“Don’t do the theater,” he said instead. “Do a bake sale. Bake sales are better.”

“We have to make art,” she said.

“You’ll lose your audience,” he said. “And you’ll deserve it.”

She left, offended in a way that would become a story she told later at wine.

At sunset, he walked home by way of the river because the river did not notice monkeys. The river did not notice him. He stopped on the bridge. The bridge shook. A barrel went by, on fire, as if old movies had come to live in their city. He wanted to throw the barrel a graph.

He didn’t call Miriam. He did not tell her he would not let anyone take Rory. He did not tell her he might have to.

When he got home, the hallway was full of smoke. Not a lot. The little kind. The almost. He opened his door fast and went in and heard a popping sound from the kitchen like old film burning. He ran. The stove was off. The note drawer was open. On the counter, a monkey sat with its hand in the sugar jar, looking at him like a cousin. It patted its chest, as if to say, me. He picked up a broom and the monkey leapt to the ceiling lamp and swung, and the lamp went into the ceiling with a sound like a bell. The monkey dropped to the floor and ran down the hall and out the door, which someone had left open on purpose, he thought, but he didn’t know who the someone was.

He shut the notes in the refrigerator. He laughed at himself, in the mad way you laugh when you’ve done something the opposite of clever. He told himself: this is the first chapter of a book you do not want to read, and he was not wrong, though he was not right, either. He washed his hands. He drank water. He dialed Miriam’s number. He did not hit call.

He opened his ledger, the paper one he kept for himself, because his mother had raised him to keep one even when the computer was a sweet singer. He wrote:

Uncle’s Tithe: not acceptable, not edible.

Rory: boy, camera, blue hair, loves olives, hates ladder into wrong house.

Miriam: forehead, coffee, rightness like a stone you could sit on.

City: on fire but only a little. On fire enough.

Monkeys: rude; reckless; chorus; mirror.

Bright Snow: future. Ash. Winter. It rhymes and he wants to refuse the rhyme.

He shut the book. He put the book under the table. He sat on the floor as if floors were seats. The world outside scraped its nails against the brick. You could hear sirens sometimes, the real ones. You could hear calliope music. You could hear a profound quiet when a troop crossed the street like an army of toddlers. He put his head on his knees. He did not cry. He weighed crying like a purchase and decided to save his money.

The Harvest Moon was a month away. None of the calendars said it. All of the calendars knew it. The monkeys, who had learned the shape of time the way a child learns to whistle, were already humming the new song, their voices a net thrown over the city, the holes very small.By the next morning the city had found a new way to pretend it was ordinary, which is to say the baker had opened on time and a monkey had already stolen a bag of flour and upended it in the gutter so the sidewalk wore a white rash. Ephraim stepped around the powdered patch and thought, because he could not help it, of the phrase bright snow and the way it lived under everything now, a refrigerator hum in his head. He took the stairs to save his arms from the elastic humiliation of the tram straps. On the landing between the third and fourth floors someone had taped a flyer over an old exterminator advertisement: SENSEFUL STREETS ROUNDTABLE—PUBLIC PARTICIPATION WELCOME. Below in marker, a hand that could have been a boy’s or a monkey’s had added: UNCLE BRINGS SNACKS. The marker had bled through the paper and stained the plaster wall in a shape like a mouth opening.

At Kettle & Hart, the usual ten-floor howl had tuned itself to morning radio; the monkeys had learned to imitate an ad for life insurance and were practicing it with great seriousness from the fluorescent light tracks, the phrase “your loved ones” coming out like a growl with an opinion. Darla handed him a sealed envelope with a municipal seal and a cartoon banana pressed into the wax as if it were a crest. Her blouse had turned the color of lawful envy. She kept her face still the way brave people do when they don’t want to make you into a project. “This came by messenger with a vestibule escort,” she said. “They made me sign three times with three different pens. I used all of them wrong.”

He slit the wax with the edge of his thumbnail, which had been made for lesser tasks, and unfolded a summons printed on thick paper that wanted to be a birth certificate. It invited—required—requested his attendance at a midnight session of the Consultative Panel on Equilibrium, to be held in a municipal chamber he had never set foot in, labeled in a font too whimsical to be legal: The Hall of Balances. The letter stressed confidentiality, dignity, and the spiritual seriousness of civic arithmetic. The time—midnight—crackled with ritual like a bonfire concealed under a tarp. The bottom carried the mayor’s rubber signature and the City’s motto, which had always embarrassed him: We Add, We Endure, We Eat What We Must.

Hart appeared at his door before he had a chance to fold the paper into a smaller truth. His tie looked like it had given up and was resting between the knots. He glanced at the summons and whistled quietly, a sound that used to call dogs and now called monkeys, although none came. “They’ve decided to get holy,” Hart said, and let himself in as if the office were a conversation. “Did you bring olives for lunch? Bring olives. You’ll need the salt.”

“They want me at midnight,” Ephraim said. “They want me where there are no hours.”

“They want you where clocks dress in robes,” Hart said, with the kind of gallows brightness that gets men invited to panels. He leaned against the bookcase and bumped it with the soft inexorability of a ship into a dock. “Don’t be alone in there. If they say you’re symbolic, say you’re heavy. Symbolic is cheap. Heavy breaks tables.”

“It’s a theater,” Ephraim said. “A theater where they’ll hand me a knife made of vowels.”

Hart looked past him into the pane of glass where a juvenile macaque was attempting to see how many paperclips it could put into its nose. “The theater is the economy right now,” he said, and his voice dropped a half inch. “There’s rumor that the tithe isn’t a tithe unless the market sees it, that the number doesn’t count unless the head nods and the cameras cut to tears. The monkeys know it’s a show and the money knows it’s a show and the City believes it’s a sacrament. We have more audiences than actors.”

“Have you made a deal?” Ephraim asked, because he had to ask, because the thought had been scratching his ribs.

Hart’s smile moved left, then right, then left again, as if it had a turn signal. “I signed a letter that said I’d show up for the talk and bring a colander of jokes,” he said. “And I said I would not, under any circumstances, put my hands on a boy. I said that on paper. Sometimes paper is a way of making your hands known to yourself.” He touched the edge of Ephraim’s desk with two fingers, as if it might ask for a blessing. “Don’t go alone. Take a witness. Or take a camera. Or take both and tell one to be quiet.”

The afternoon had the shape of an overnumerous book. When he could not stare any longer at a cell that equaled itself with a smugness he could not stand, he opened the City’s parcel map and typed in 999 Cherry Road. The map blinked. The road extruded, then retracted. A light gray outline swam into being where a block should be, then faded, as if the block were waiting backstage and the stage manager had not called its name. He found an archival layer from twenty years back and there it was, Cherry Road, a neat line, a small orchard marked with a green fill, a cannery that had been given a little factory icon like the ones in children’s books. The cannery had been decommissioned and then recommissioned as lofts and then condemned and then, apparently, subtracted. A red notice marker toggled on and off like a heartbeat.

He called a number he was not supposed to have. On the seventh ring a woman answered with her voice wrapped in a scarf. “Geographic Information Services,” she said, and then, as if only one person could have this number, “Oh. The accountant.”

“The pen-chewer,” he said, and regretted it. “I’m looking at a parcel that keeps changing its mind. 999 Cherry Road.”

“We call that the vanishing tooth,” the analyst said. “It’s an error we don’t fix because every time we fix it a monkey shows up in the server room and pulls a cable with the exact tenderness of a midwife. There’s an overlay, Mr. Cole. There’s always an overlay. I can send you a screenshot if you promise to look at it and then delete it from your mind.”

“I’ll try,” he said. He gave her his private email and received an image that made his heartbeat go tight. The parcel was annotated: BRIGHT BRIDGES TEMPORARY. Under that: CASH PICKUP—UNDER RIVER VIADUCT K. Under that: COMMUNITY APPEASEMENT—FUN. The F’s legba had been rubbed out, leaving UN.

In the late light he found Lark on the museum steps with a satchel and a grin that had gotten into a fight with reality and lost, but only on points. The professor produced from the bag a thin bone-brown stick carved with a tidy ladder of lines, notches worn down by fingers that had belonged to men who had not known that monkeys could be a committee. “In case they ask for proof,” Lark said, and passed the tally to Ephraim the way one passes a warm difficult object to a friend. “We used to reckon with things we could hold. People trusted us because their hands could touch the count.”

“I have a place,” Ephraim said. “A parcel that pretends to evaporate. 999 Cherry Road.”

Lark made a small face that combined delight and dread into a sauce. “Yes,” he said. “Yes, and yes. My student Sheila filmed monkeys there last month wearing hard hats and handing out candy that was also a card with a QR code that led to a clip of the mayor saying the word accommodate. Then the place was gone and the clip had a cat in it that nobody owned.”

“I want to see the place when it’s pretending to be a place,” Ephraim said. “I want to know if rituals come with lighting technicians.”

Rory appeared from behind the bronze statue of a coin, hands deep in jacket pockets, hair still blue but with dark at the roots like an old lake meeting a newer one. He stood with the showman's patience of a teenager trying not to make it apparent that he had been waiting for the adults to get to the part with the verbs. “If you’re going,” he said, “I’m filming. I already filmed the barber fire and a monkey throwing up into a boot, and I should probably also film the part of the movie where the uncle becomes a diagram.”

“We talked about ribs,” Miriam said from the step above, and for a second Ephraim’s brain put her there in the picture with Rory where she always went when he imagined them without himself. She had on her coat with the elbow mended and a scarf with cherries on it, because the universe could still be literal when it wanted to hurt you. “We talked, and you will text me the address of every place you plan to set foot in, and you will use your camera as a shield, not as a sword, and if anything stinks like a plan to make you into a poem, you will leave.”

“You’re here,” Ephraim said. It came out like gratitude wrapped in accusation.

“Of course,” she said. “I brought you an apple because you are not going to eat dinner if you’re practicing being a moat.” She touched his cheek with the back of her fingers the way their mother had touched them when she wanted to count what was still warm.

They walked as a clump under a sky that had put on metal and gone out for the evening. The blocks near the vanished parcel had become a different city than the one on the map: signs replaced by drawings with bulging eyes and tongues; a dry cleaner turned into a studio where a monkey—dressed in plastic pearls and a felt hat—was painting a wall with big black words that said NO, THEN YES, THEN NO again as if the city had to be told every minute which way to tilt. A group of rhesus youths had made themselves a court and were arguing over a stolen sandwich with gestures that mimed gavels and crossed arms that meant the law. A woman with a bundle of something too soft to be laundry stopped and watched, then took out her phone, then put it away with a care that showed she had remembered the cost of losing the smallest thing you have left.

Cherry Road turned and stopped. Where the map insisted there should be an address, there was a drawing in chalk on a section of cinderblock: a doorway, very detailed, with hinges shaded into suggestion and a knob drawn as if it could be turned. A vervet reached for the chalk and added a tiny keyhole, then looked at them to see if they would applaud. Behind the chalk door the wall was blank except for a stain shaped like an island and a vertical seam where at some point the city had welded something shut. If you put your ear against it the concrete felt like a muted drum. Rory did. He pulled away with a grin that tried to straddle terror and joy. “There are trucks in there,” he said. “There is refrigeration. There is a conversation that sounds like people who don’t want their voices to know their faces.”

From the alley to the left of the chalk door a van slunk into the street with its headlights off and an orchard printed on its vinyl wrap, glossy cherries fit to burst. Bananas, lashed to the roof with rough rope, made a little yellow crown you would expect to see in a children’s parade. Beside the driver sat a mandrill in a jacket that could have been satin or could have been a reflection of something else trying to be expensive. The mandrill’s eyes, cataracted at the edges, had the bored disdain of a recurring donor. On the rear bumper a small sticker with the City seal had lost a letter so it read PUBL C. The van turned its wheel reluctantly, like a creature doing the thing it had always done while dreaming of a different command, and rolled toward the river.

Lark put his hand lightly on Ephraim’s arm in the friend’s version of a brake. “Follow without being,” he said, which was not a sentence that meant anything until it did. Rory fell back and flipped his camera on, the lens sucking light with a purr. They slipped alongside the block like conspirators pretending to be strollers. A troop had taken up a chant that was almost nice if you didn’t translate it. A macaque with a newborn riding its back as if mother had been turned into public transport reached a hand toward Rory’s hair and then withdrew it because the blue spooked it. Near the viaduct an old cannery had been facaded into modern with glass panels and then defaced back into honest with rocks. The van slid into the cannery’s old loading dock like a memory into a void, the wide mouth swallowing and then pretending it had never eaten.

Inside, the air kept different accounts. Cold came from the walls. Warmth came from the exhalations of men in municipal polo shirts who were not smiling because their faces had learned that muscles could be watched. A stack of boxes wore the label BRIGHT BRIDGES in a font that said “Please, we are decent,” and another stack wore no label at all but the cargo speaks: paper, much paper, reams and sheaves and rolls like a banquet for goats. On a whiteboard an internish human hand had diagrammed a calendar with hearts around the Harvest Moon and an event titled in large letters: UNCLE’S PORTION—BROADCAST WINDOW. Under it in a different hand: Call Insurance. Make Snow.

The mandrill in satin jacket accepted from an eager human a small black thing that might have been a phone or a remote or a trigger. She—this was the same mandrill, Ephraim realized with the small nausea of recognition, the one who had licked the mike in the rotunda and had not afterward gotten sick—touched the device, and a bank of lights flicked on, illuminating a stage that had been made out of pallets and city money. There were props: a ledger, a knife that gleamed with theatrical intent, a bowl, a cheap crown. One of the monkeys in a railworker’s cap hopped onto the pallets and made a speech to the others that was ninety percent insult and ten percent instruction. The instruction was to howl at the moment when the crowd does not know if it ought to cheer.

Rory filmed without breathing. Lark mouthed something that could have been the Nicene Creed of accountants, which is to say he mouthed numbers in a sequence meant to bind a panic. Ephraim recognized his own name on a clipboard under a column that said: TALENT. Beside his name, someone had written in a cursive that wanted to be calligraphy, Clean if possible.

A voice came from his left, too close to be safe and too gentle to be hated. “You shouldn’t see this until everyone does,” the woman from Cultural Affairs said, and smiled the way you smile when you bump into a friend at a funeral and do not yet know if you’re both supposed to be there. Her candle smell was faint; the cannery smell was stronger. Her hair was pinned with a green bobby pin that wished it were an emerald. “I told you we’re making a play. We’re just doing it in a space with better acoustics than the city’s failing theater. People listen to concrete.”

“You’re laundering policy through art,” Lark said, a little too pleased to be able to accuse anyone of something that had such good rhythm. “You’re feeding the appetite you pretend to satisfy.”

She didn’t look at him. She kept her eyes on Ephraim as if his face were a ledger whose totals could not be fudged. “We’ve modeled it,” she said, and the word model floated between them like a paper ship almost on fire. “The thing that keeps the rail spurs open long enough to move the fuel and the sea-grain away from the plant in the south is a spectacle that takes the troops off the bridges and the alleys and leaves three hours of unmonkeyed road. The chemical engineers tell me the chillers go from safe to hymn in twenty-seven minutes if the power goes. If the ammonia goes, we get what your friend called bright snow. It’s not a metaphor to them, Mr. Cole. To them it’s a forecast.”

“Then tell them,” Ephraim said. “Tell them the facts. Monkeys aren’t allergic to facts. They just like them in costume.”

“We tried,” she said. “They threw facts in the fountain because they floated. They like things that sink. They like a number that gets wet and falls apart. We tried to give them the math without blood. They ate the paper and asked for salt.” She stepped away, then back, as if the air had a mind. “If you stand on that pallet and cut what we hand you, you buy us time to move tankers out of the county. If you refuse, you become a different kind of show, and we don’t get the hour. I have to speak to you in cruel clarity because I am tired in a way that doesn’t permit any more embroidery.”

He heard his phone vibrate the way a heart sometimes remembers it has a job. His sister’s name on the screen made his throat find its mystery. He silenced it, because he needed his hands to be empty to hear the woman say the part she should not say. She leaned in and said it, voice lowered to the register where things are called true because no one else can hear. “The first note was not wrong,” she said. “Someone likes you enough to put faith in your stomach.” She looked at the stage and then at the vans with the cherries, which had their doors open like open mouths waiting for laughter. “If there were a way to do this with counterfeit, I would say counterfeit, and we would print a child of paper and feed it to the crowd. But then the crowd would leave with the taste of ink, and they would go to the hospital, and the power would go, and a different ink would print itself on the sky.”

A small shape at the edge of the dock turned and looked at them with the fascination of someone who goes to the movies for the popcorn. The vervet from the chalk door had found them, its hands chalked like a mason’s, and it started to open its mouth and call down a rain of notice. Rory, quicker than a bond trader inventing derivatives, lifted his camera and pointed the lens at the monkey and whispered please. The monkey was vain enough to postpone betrayal to admire its own reflection in a glass it could not break. It grinned, then bit the edge of the lens in a gesture that had no meaning until it did. Its bite left a crescent and the monkey left a giggle and a piss-shiver and ran to tell the world anyway.

The first guard to turn tracked wrong and saw Lark first because Lark looked like guilt. His hand went to a baton and then to a radio and then to his face because a flock of pigeons rose from the rafters with the thunder of things that are both dumb and numerous, and they startled him into performing a dance that made his dignity buy a hat. The pigeons had been sleeping in the beams until the mandrill pressed the magic remote and filled the room with warm lumens. When confronted with light, pigeons believe they are applause. Lark, because he had been born for this sort of unlikely tutelage, lifted his whistle and blew three short and one long and set the flock’s nouns flying toward the stage. Feathers hit satin with the soft decisiveness of receipts thrown into a fan. The mandrill swore in a language that had been learned from longshoremen and children. A human dropped a clipboard and the papers went far, because paper goes farther than anyone thinks, and one sheet with Ephraim’s name on it sailed under a pallet and hid as if paper had learned loyalty.

They ran because bodies ask for mercy from thinking. Concrete under shoe, soft shadows that did not belong to humans, the fish-smell of a river that had believed its job was to carry. They would have been caught in a different city. This city, right now, was arguing with itself about whether you catch the people who came to see you when you were breaking the law dressed as mercy. At the dock’s mouth a bandaged capuchin had mounted a forklift and was trying to reverse time with it, the machine’s beep-beep-beep announcing the monkey’s sense of crisis. When it saw Ephraim it scrubbed its face with its hand in an expression that had come from men who miss trains. “Pen-chewer,” it said with a glee that made a joke on a ledge, then jerked its head in the direction of an exit disguised as a no-exit sign. “Uncle shortcut. Go, go. You owe me a bite.”

They went, because otters know where the river deepens and sometimes monkeys know where walls forget themselves for a minute. A corridor smelling of hair and dust coughed them into the alley behind the cannery where a truck with bad brakes sighed at the curb. The Cultural Affairs woman had followed and reached the door as they disappeared; she did not shout wait. She put her palm flat to the cold metal and closed her eyes long enough to memorize a prayer, then turned and walked back into the building because her job had refused private vows for her.

They hid in the museum because everyone hides in a church when they’ve been doing math with knives. Lark took them under the diorama of a medieval counting room where the mannequins wore faces that implied only medium concern. He opened a drawer with a key that had never been friendly and took out a ledger fragment that had been stolen, then returned, then catalogued as a lesson about wrong. On the page the word that meant uncle looked like the word that meant creditor if you bent your head. Lark tapped the ink with one finger as if tapping could undo sorrow. “There were substitutions,” he said, and his voice did not shake as much as Ephraim expected. “In one village, the uncle was the vessel for the debt. They called the man uncle because to love him was to love the thing you owed. When the season failed, they killed the ledger. They drowned it, or they burned it, or they fed it to the oxen and then argued about whether eating by proxy solved anything. There is a fresco in Bologna where a line of men in shirts carry an account book to a river as if it is a boy made of paper. Someone could have said, This is childish. Someone might have said, Our enemies will laugh. But the winter after that there wasn’t a famine. That’s the kind of story people keep by mistake.”

“We can feed them numbers,” Rory said, softly, as if softness could keep the walls from hearing. He held up his camera like an oath. “We can make them into food. We can print whatever this Uncle’s Fund is—whatever the pages say the city  owns of itself—and we can burn that instead. We can bring it in boxes with cherries on them and let the monkeys tear the paper with their teeth and we can film the sound and it will be the sound. We make a banquet of the part that is eating us already and we let it be eaten.”

“I won’t be allowed to print the city,” Ephraim said. His own voice sounded unfamiliar in the room. It had become a voice that expected to be told it was quaint. “I barely get to color the city. Darla will get a memo that says we’re all allergic to toner.”

“You don’t print the city,” Lark said. He leaned forward, eyes brighter than the time when he’d seen a potshard confirm a hunch. “You print scrip. You print bright, beautiful, edible money that stands in for the debt. Not counterfeit of currency—counterfeit of an idea. We rename Uncle’s Tithe to Uncle’s Write-off. We stage a closing of accounts. We break the ladder that goes from loss to boy and lay down a different ladder, made of paper and salt.”

“It only works if they believe the paper tastes good,” Rory said. He had turned his lens toward them and then away, filming the mannequins as if the frozen paperwork of five hundred years ago had something to say about never letting anybody get away with calling hunger a moral. “It only works if the men with the cherries and the insurance don’t give another speech in a room with better lights.”

“They’ll try,” Lark said. “Their mouths are rented. Their words are a fleet.”

A tapping sounded on the window behind the display. A monkey had retrieved a stapler from somewhere and was pretending to use it on its own tail. Another monkey, smaller, lifted a handful of something white and blew it against the glass. The something drifted down, ash from one of the small fires, catching on the window’s pitting. Bright snow, thought Ephraim, and his stomach forgot it belonged to him for a second. He stood up and the body that had always liked to calculate did the thing bodies do when they have reached a ledge and see a rope hanging: it reached for the rope.

“I need Hart,” he said. “I need a press that can make a lot of sin in a very short time. I need Darla to pretend what I am doing is a milk run. I need the mayor’s assistant to send me a list of everything we can legally paint yellow and have it not be a crime. I need Miriam not to forgive me immediately. I need her to watch it first and then decide if what I broke was smaller than what I kept.”

“I can get you the press,” Lark said, because if you stay in a museum long enough you learn that there is always an extra press leaning against a wall behind something else. “A student can get you five. The interns want to be arrested by a narrative. They have been waiting to be told what their lesson is. We can print with soy ink. It tastes like beans. We can cut the scrip into mouth-size with those terrible paper cutters that whisper about fingers. We can stamp the backs with a seal you can smell. If you can’t smell a seal, you won’t believe you should eat it.”

Rory texted someone with thumbs that had learned their alphabet while standing on buses. “I know a print shop that owes me a favor because I filmed their flood,” he said. “They have stacks they will call trash if anyone asks after them. They have a guillotine cutter with a handle you pull like a heart. They will help if we call it a pop-up.”

Miriam’s reply to the text Ephraim sent—Trust me—came back like a stone that had been warmed by a sun she had carried in her pocket. It said: I will watch. Her second text: Do not practice any vows without me. Her third: Bring the olives. That was how forgiveness in their family worked sometimes; it arrived in a bowl and you put your fingers in and got them oiled.

Back in his office, Hart listened to the plan and rolled it around his mouth as if he were testing whether the salt content would make him drink or sing. He pulled down a binder marked Retired Hardware and found in it, with the glee of a boy remembering that he had a slingshot in the attic, a permit number that belonged to a plant that had once exploded and then been rebuilt, then put out of memory and allowed to rest. “We can borrow their stamp,” he said. “They’ll think we’re honoring their contribution to the civic fabric. They’ll send snacks.”

Darla printed him three copies of a memo with the subject line: OLD PAPER DISPOSAL—NO ACTION. She affixed to each a Post-it with a cartoon banana drawn in a competent hand. “You didn’t get these from me,” she said, and tucked her hair behind her ear and gave him the look people get when they are shipping you to war and want you to come back carrying a story and not a flag. “If a monkey asks, you’re returning toner.”

They moved the first pallets of scrip at night because night had been taught to behave, to stop asking questions you could not answer with a badge. The scrip looked obscene, the way too much bread looks obscene when you stack it on a table in a room with thin people. The sheets were vivid with symbols that borrowed the authority of the City while clearly being fake in a way that could be forgiven because the fake tasted like something. The seal said: SUBSTITUTE. The line under it said: THE CITY EATS ITS PAPER TO SAVE ITS PEOPLE. Under that, in small print that was more confession than law: This is a ritual. It may stain.

When the monkeys came to sniff—and of course they came, because monkeys adore the smell of any new permission—they tasted and then made their faces, the good faces, the ones that say I didn’t know I was hungry for this. They cackled and threw little handfuls in the air and the paper drifted like forgiving weather. A troupe chanted a nonsense hymn to food that wasn’t food, and the rhyme scheme held. Rory filmed from a truck bed and caught the moment an old woman in a hat with fake cherries tore a scrip sheet into strips and fed one piece ceremoniously to the capuchin with the bandaged ear. The monkey chewed with the slow solemnity of a critic. It smacked and then said, in a human tone it had learned to use only when it really meant to be heard, “Salt,” and the crowd laughed and the laughter lifted.

He could feel, even before he saw it, the shape of the countershow being set on the pallets in the cannery, the stage’s wood sweating under lights, the bowl waiting to be filled with the thing that would make the calendar keep going. He could feel the chemical plant beyond the south rail spurs straining, something inside it pressing its cheek to the glass of its own container. The phone lit with a message from the Cultural Affairs woman that did not art at all. It said: Two hours, if you can hold them. Then another: Please be vulgar. It pulls them harder.

They were vulgar. They were shameless. They were financial. At the Hall of Balances, which turned out to be in the basement of City Hall with a fresco of scales and a leak in the corner, the mayor and four men who had shaved twice that day waited with their lapel flags and their bottled water and their list of words not to say. At midnight, the time they had chosen because it sounded like guilt, the hall was empty except for the people whose schedules no longer belonged to them and one mandrill who had come to see if the City would embarrass itself properly. Ephraim brought scrip in. He put a stack on the table like a man bringing bread to a meeting that might kill him. He looked at the mayor and saw a man made of calculations, and it moved something in him like pity shaking a hinge, just a little.

“We won’t do the boy,” he said, and the words, when said, made a shape in the room that had not been available to them before. He held up a page stamped SUBSTITUTE and saw how the mandrill’s eyes blinked in a pattern that could have been grief. “We will do the ledger. We will do the paper you have been hiding under names made of cousins. We’ll do it now. The city will watch, and then the city will eat.”

The mayor rubbed his forehead like a man polishing a coin. He looked at the mandrill, as if the animal had become his conscience, and the mandrill bared its teeth the way laughter bares teeth. The Cultural Affairs woman nodded, very slightly. Hart stood at the back and looked like a ship’s mast. Darla would never know she had been in the room, and she would keep that as a good thing tucked into her desk like a holy card.

Outside, the first crowd was forming around the pop-up and the second crowd was forming around the rumor that something was about to make a different kind of sense. A few flakes of ash had begun again, slow and idiotic, not ominous yet, the way bad news sometimes enters from an angle. Monkeys lined the rooftops with the patience of men who have been promised a cannon. Somewhere, a horn played a note that was almost minor and then corrected itself. The city inhaled, the sound of a place that had learned that breath is a vote, and Ephraim lifted the first stack of substitute debt and held it for the hands that were waiting. He thought of Miriam’s texts, a little drizzle of olive oil on everything, and of Rory’s camera recording history’s second take, and of Lark’s bone stick, a ladder for tiny fingers, and he thought, with the clarity of a man who has tried to imagine himself a knife and has shied, that one of the uses of a city might be to write new numbers down and make them true.

He did not like that he had become the person who had to say the next sentence out loud. He did not like that the sentence he was about to say was both a con and a rescue. He shook his head once to make the bad part fall out and found that nothing fell. He put his hand on the pile of edible paper, looked at the mayor, and then looked at the mandrill, and then looked at the room, and then, because someone had to start, he said, “Eat.”The city ate. It did not do it neatly, because nothing since the monkeys arrived had been neat, but it did it with the sincerity of hunger meeting a form it could recognize. In the Hall of Balances the first mouth to close on the scrip was the mandrill’s, though later the mayor would say, hand on heart, that he had led. She took a sheet between her molars, bored eyes flicking from Ephraim to the knife on the ceremonial cloth and back again, and she chewed like a scholar who distrusts every source. When she swallowed, a murmur went around the room that had a shape like applause trying not to get arrested. The mayor tore a corner, grimaced as the soy salt hit his tongue, and performed the swallowing with a theatricality that made his tie look like a prop. Hart did it with a grin, Darla with the prim satisfaction of a woman who had learned to take communion and later learned to keep a ledger. The Cultural Affairs woman did not eat; she stood by the door like a match in a box and let her eyes do the chewing.

Outside the Hall, in the open-lit rooms of the city where nothing was secret anymore unless it was printed in a font from the wrong century, the pop-ups bloomed. They called them, because people will always name a procession they don’t fully understand, paper feasts, write-off tables, Uncle’s buffet. The first one at the cannery dock had epaulets of monkeys along the roofline who made a music of their own with their teeth. The second, in front of the Countinghouse, was a solemn affair officiated by Lark in his numbered tie, who insisted on telling each volunteer, as if the city needed a liturgy, what a ledger was and why you could drown it and still keep your house. Rory climbed onto a truck bed and filmed until his battery sang low and then stole a charge from a sympathetic fruit stand that had decided oranges were a kind of ornament for civic rites. Miriam stood by the olive bowl to which she had held him earlier and passed out green eyes to those who wanted to wash the ink taste from their mouths. She had the face she wore when she might soon need to forgive.

The chant, once the monkeys decided it, hummed across blocks: Eat the paper, keep the breath. Eat the paper, keep the wheels. They liked any song that could be clapped, and the clapping carried the sheets into fingers that had always meant to hold a little more than they did. In the south, where the rail spurs quivered like the veins in a too-thin wrist, an engineer with a stutter counted backward in his head and watched the gauge climb and then wobble and then drop as the load pulled out. He did not believe in magic, but he believed in minutes, and the pop-up showed him its face in all the cars that were not in his way. The “bright snow” remained a phrase, which is to say it remained potential, which is to say he went home that night and put his children to bed and did not open the drawer with the pills that promise to smooth your breathing.

The cannery stage, robbed of its boy and its camera-ready throat, pivoted. The mandrill flicked the remote and the pallets rolled, the bowl was filled with shredded scrip instead of something that breathed, and an underpaid man whose job did not include the word faith lit a match to a line of fuel poured under the props to give the spectacle its necessary hiss. The monkeys jeered and then, because mockery tires like anything, they laughed and stuffed their mouths with the softened substitute. A faction on the rafters banged pipes in a rhythm that had been used to call men to work and later to call them to wake. A smaller faction hissed the word “cowards” in human language and jumped from beam to beam with a purpose that smelled like coming trouble. The Cultural Affairs woman stood near the soundboard in a dress that looked like it could be washed with a sponge and gave hand signals to a technician who translated theatre into weather.

News crawled across screens in that mutant idiom the city had taught its anchors: “City chooses carbs over carnage,” said one. “Uncle’s Appetite Satisfied by Scrip,” said another, and then, in smaller font that bit the eye, “Chem Plant Avoids Worst-Case.” An online magazine called it “ritual arbitrage” and posted a photo of a rhesus with soy-ink on its chin. Commenters did what they always did, composed small epics of rage and wit and injury, and out of the noise one coherent current announced itself like a river showing its channel: we will let a paper cut us if it keeps the knives off the table.

Kettle & Hart smelled like glue and victory on the morning after. The monkeys had found the shredder and fed it a scarf and called it opera. Darla changed her blouse for one the color of queenly patience and arranged a stack of memos in a line that looked like a road out of town. Hart took his shoes off in his office and put his feet on the radiator, which did not work, and declared himself a small nation with a hot climate. He was pleased in a tender way that made Ephraim want to forgive him for the jokes he would make later at bars that would pretend to be sober. He clapped once when Ephraim went by, not for the prank of it but as a private sacrament, and then he said, “You printed a thing and then you made it true. That’s the deepest sin we have and also the only virtue left to us.”

“You say that like you’ve been practicing in front of a mirror,” Ephraim said, and then smiled to take the edge off the truth.

“I have,” Hart said. “I write my lines on the bathroom tile with my finger and watch the steam erase them. It makes me feel like a gentleman.” He lowered his feet. “There’ll be blowback. There’s always blowback when you satisfy an appetite that wanted a different menu. The mayor will attempt to name the ritual after a park. The Council will recommend that we establish a committee on edible paper standards. Cultural Affairs will hire a choreographer. A faction will call it cowardice. A different faction will call it cannibalism anyway, because they love a long word more than they love mercy.”

In the late morning, an email with the subject line PUBLIC SIMIAN INTEGRATION FUND—CLARIFICATIONS landed in Ephraim’s inbox and split into five smaller emails as if it had been built by lizards. The first declared the success of last night’s intervention and attached a PDF with photos of monkeys mid-chew that would surely be printed in a magazine where the layout designer had a grudge against captions. The second asserted that Uncle’s Tithe had been sunsetted and replaced by Uncle’s Write-off, a phrase that made his stomach do a small, intractable thing. The third admonished all parties to refrain from politicizing what was purely an economic ritual. The fourth announced the establishment of a permitting process for public consumption of scrip, complete with an application that required, in triplicate, proof of olive procurement. The fifth reminded him, personally, to keep to grayscale and to remember that color was for parks.

Lark arrived with a hand full of newspaper and the air of a man who has found himself on the right side of a legend and is grateful but bewildered.
