He laid the pages on Ephraim’s desk and smoothed them with a palm as if all paper deserved gentled. “They’re going to ask you to do it once a week,” he said. “They’re going to ask you to put it on the calendar like trash day, and they will do it with the equivocal blessing of the mandrill and the open question of the monkeys who wanted to see you bleed. They cannot help themselves. Systems want to be seasons.”

“I’m not erecting a holiday,” Ephraim said. “I’m not making a cake. We did it to get the trucks through.”

“Trucks will need to get through every week,” Lark said, and shrugged with the apology of a man who has broken hearts by describing a stone. “Once you feed a city a story, it stands on the corner at the same time the next day to see if the story will come back around.”

He took the long way to lunch because he couldn’t bear the strap-song of the tram with its music of monkeys and metal fatigue. Miriam was waiting on a bench with a bag of cherries that looked like proof a tree could still be a parent. She handed him the bag without ceremony and leaned her head on his shoulder for a number of seconds that had its own unit of measure. Rory sat on the ground, cross-legged, camera on his knee, editing with the kind of focused shamelessness that makes art indifferent to its audience. When he looked up, Ephraim saw that a sleep had moved across his face like a small tide and left a mark that made him look more mortal, which is to say more here.

“It worked,” Rory said without asking a question. “I have footage of a macaque with paper in its teeth looking at the lens like the lens had committed a sin. I have a woman wearing a hat with cherries wiping her mouth after she ate the seal with SUBSTITUTE on it as if she had kissed someone she didn’t want anyone to know about. I have the mandrill” —and here his voice got that thin shimmer of disbelief— “smiling with ink on her gums. I could make thirty different films. I’m going to make one and it’s going to be about you and it’s also not going to be about you at all.”

“I don’t want to be a hero,” Ephraim said, because you have to say it, and also because he meant it, and also because he knew it had no power to redirect anything.

“Good,” Rory said. “Heroes are inconvenient to everyone. I’d rather film a person who solved a gross problem with a grosser joke.”

Miriam chewed a cherry and spit the pit into her palm the way a lady might spit a bullet that someone had fired to make a point. “We’re not done,” she said, when she had her mouth back. “I woke up at four because the radio told me to and I had a thought I hated and then I kept it because maybe hating is a way of knowing it’s important. If the city wants to make this a ritual, we can keep showing up with our paper and our olives, but—” She paused, because words like but can carry a house on their back. “There’s a cost to pretending to eat a boy. Even if the mouth knows it’s paper, the mind learns a posture. Rory says film can teach us a posture and unteach it, but film is a slow teacher. Do we want that posture in the city’s spine.”

“I don’t,” Ephraim said, and his voice did a little thing it does when it runs into a wall where an answer hides. “But I do want the part where we don’t freeze to death in snowfall made of wrong. I keep seeing it when I close my eyes. It looks like someone emptied flour in the street and then told you to breathe deep.”

“Then we do it once,” Miriam said. “We do it twice if the trucks say please. We don’t do it a third time unless the river changes its mind. We pretend to the city that we are creatures who can leave a habit before the habit has a chance to make a hoodie out of us.”

He wanted to say yes to everything she said because she was his sister and because the little theater of his life had always played better with her in the front row, but the habit he had made of truth tapped at his ribs. “They’ve already sent a memo,” he said. “They have a form and a seal. They’re going to ask for live music. They’re going to ask for children to hold the banners because children make the news camera turn into a dog that lies down.”

Miriam’s mouth tightened. “Then I will hold the banner and bite the reporter,” she said, and they both smiled, because if you can’t laugh while you’re deciding how not to feed your family to an idea, you will cry until your eyes forget how to do anything else.

By evening the improvisation had become a procession. Men who liked to coordinate told people where to stand and the people ignored them. A troop of spider monkeys discovered that if they held the paper under the tap in the park it turned into something like soup, and that if you drank that you got the sensation of having eaten a complicated thought, and the sensation was satisfying if you were made of nerves. A bar made cocktails with a garnish of substitute scrip and called them Uncle’s Apology. A child no one knew put two pieces of scrip under a rock and declared he had planted a money tree and then wept when the monkeys dug it up and wore the pieces like eyebrows. The police put tape around nothing and then took the tape down and wore it as headbands. A butcher taped a sign to his window that read: We Sell Only Animals, Not Narratives, and a clever rhesus corrected it to Not Yet. In the south the tankers cleared the crossing and a man with a vest cried into his safety glasses where no one could see it and then went into the break room and ate a whole bag of potato chips without tasting a thing.

At the Cannery, where everything had started wanting to be real and had been redirected into real enough, the mandrill watched with half-closed eyes while a troupe of her cousins tore the substitute into necklaces. She had a way of scratching her shoulder that was primate and also very much like a woman in a nice chair remembering a song. When Ephraim came within earshot she made a sound that was not speech but was the sound old women in his family made when someone they had worried about walked in breathing. “You bought the hour,” she said, in the language you use to hand a person a coin and ask them not to inspect its edges. “The others will say it was their whistle or their tantrum, but you bought it, and I will not forget that until forgetting becomes fashionable again.”

He thought of asking her what she had wanted him to do with the knife, if he had chosen the other road, but the monkey in her brows made him stop. “Will they accept this every time,” he asked instead, and he knew he was being a bureaucrat even as he felt the shame of it. “Will your theatre hold.”

“Some of them want blood,” she said, and the words came out so evenly it took his skin a beat to prickle. “Some of them want wheat. Some of them want only to throw rocks and see what noise the glass makes. We will argue among ourselves in a way that looks like dancing to you. The little ones will love the taste and the noise. The old will get belly aches and call in sick to scratching. The males with opinions will stand up high and make announcement after announcement until their throats hurt. There will be a day when nothing works and your paper tastes like a lie and our children bite your fingers. But—” Her gaze flicked to the empty stage and then to the river, and for a moment she was only animal in a running world. “Not tonight.”

When he reached his building the bakery had kept the light on over the glass case like a watchman who needed company. He bought a bag of yesterday’s rolls because the women in his family had taught him about thrift and because carrying bread had started to feel like carrying a signature. The baker, who had always looked like a saint in a painting that someone had given up trying to sell, shook his head at the news and said, in the simple language he saved for meat and for grief, that the numbers would not help him if the flour trucks didn’t stop being afraid. Ephraim promised him he would print something for the trucks to eat if they refused to move, and the baker laughed so carefully the air stayed where it was supposed to.

Back upstairs, the notes in the refrigerator had fogged. He took them out and read them again, because his brain had a chewiness that demanded he test the flavor until it faded. The first note’s command had dulled since he had put it under the cold; the second looked absurd, like a child’s threat; the third, which he had not read in the anger of the smoke, was written in the same careful hand and said only: You are late. He held it under his nose and the sugar-smell rose again, interleaved with something like clean cardboard. He thought of the Cultural Affairs woman and her candle. He thought of the bakery and its dusting sugar and the devastation of flour if it chose to float. He thought of the cannery and its cherries, the packhouse and its labels, the van with its orchard wrap. He thought about who in a city writes pretty and who writes cruel, and found that the list overlapped in a way that made his throat thick.

Sleep came as a collection of visits rather than a single stay. In one, his mother was adding and he was subtracting, and she smiled the way a woman smiles when the man in the suit tells her a number that will decide a week. In another, the monkeys had learned to staple clouds to the sky and were trying to keep the weather from leaving. In a third, he watched a ledger drown in a river and found that it floated, that the ink bled into the water and turned the current into a sentence that said, in a language he had taught his career not to understand, not every debt gets paid.

He woke with a conviction that frightened him, which is that life wanted to make the ritual weekly and that he would have to break it before it hardened into a law. He lay with it for a while, as you lie with a fever to see if it will pass, and then he sat up and wrote in his paper ledger the only sentence he could write about it: habit is hunger wearing a suit. He folded the ledger back into its old patience and went to the window. The morning was cloudy in every way that word could be meant. The monkeys had hung strings between the fire escapes and were trying the concept of laundry; two socks, a shirt, something that might once have been a bra but had given itself to a performance, a page of substitute scrip with a bite taken out of it clipped by two old teeth.

The day brought the first formal assertion by a group with a font: SENSEFUL STREETS issued a statement on paper the color of sidewalk that said, in words too symmetrical to be believed, that the city had traded integrity for chewing gum. A different group, whose press releases had until now been concerned chiefly with birds, applauded the ritual as a victory for symbolic diets. The mayor announced the creation of a task force wearily called The Ritual Advisory Council, and in the same breath denied that any ritual existed and insisted that if it did exist it had always been part of the civic charm. Darla brought him a donut that had been made by a monkey at the bus depot learning to fry and said she would fight anyone who tried to make her eat paper instead of pastry on Fridays.

On the second night, a counter-rite took place in the Ward with the broken clock, which was always late and therefore was often right. A troupe of capuchins with faces like badgers held up a drawing of a boy and stabbed it with plastic knives. The human crowd did not cheer. It did not hiss. It made a noise he had heard only twice before—the night his mother’s factory closed and the day he had to tell Miriam that their father had given away some money that had never been his to give. It was a noise of pure, unembellished sick. The capuchins dropped the knives the way a child drops a stick after a dog growls. Someone in the back started singing the paper chant and it spread like mold. The plastic knives ended the night in the fountain, fossilized under a layer of public water that had long since learned to accept.

He went to the plant in the south three days after the first rite because he had to see what it was he had bought with the city’s mouth. The engineer with the stutter showed him gauges with needles that moved calmly now, fat and almost smug. The chillers hummed with a tone that suggested satisfaction without arrogance. A man on a lift waved. A woman with a clipboard made a checkmark that felt like the opposite of a death notice. In a side yard a piece of insulation white as flour shivered in a wind you would not know how to name if you had not earned it with a life. He stood there until his breath settled into the rhythm of machines that did not wish to explode, and then he turned to go and saw, over the fence, on a building that had been left to angels, a phrase in monkey paint that read REAL MEAT with the E crossed three times. He felt the old cold, because there is always a faction, and the faction had learned to write.

Back at Kettle & Hart, the fourth note waited on his chair. It had been slipped under the cushion, as if a polite burglar had come for a nap. The hand was the same, the neatness of someone who pens their cruelty like a clerk. It said: Substitution buys time, not debt forgiveness. The math has a stomach. We will come back in a fortnight for the due. The smear at the bottom was not sugar. He touched it and smelled it and thought it was ink, cheap and wanting to flake. He went to the window and found, because the city was no longer generous with ignorance, that a rhesus was watching him with the curiosity of a child in a museum staring at a mummy. He held the note up to the glass. The rhesus put a hand to the glass, palm to palm with him for a second, and then licked the pane and ran.

The Cultural Affairs woman texted him just before dusk to ask him to coffee and then amended it to ask him, with the boldness of someone who has run out of substitute verbs, to absolution. He met her at a place that had once been a poetry venue and was now a room where the espresso machine tried to be louder than the city. She smelled less like candle and more like scorched milk. She had not slept, or she had slept and had dreamed of a city that ate the wrong thing.

“We negotiated,” she said without saying hello. “We will change the weekly to a floating rite. We will deny it ever happened while asking you to keep a press on standby. We will ask the rail men to sign a pledge to call before they need it. We will ask the plant to create redundancies named after saints. We will try to teach the monkeys a song about chlorination. We are making a cultural practice out of a rumor. I have always wanted to earn my pension with a mural, not with a clever mouth.”

“Who wrote the notes,” he asked, because if you’re going to sit across from someone whose job is to turn blood into policy you may as well ask them to tell you who in the city writes in the hand that makes you think of grade school.

She looked into her cup as if there were ethics at the bottom. “There are three people with that hand,” she said. “One is a woman who used to teach Latin and now photographs weddings in rooms with exposed brick. One is a man who designs logistics for a grocery chain and is the only person I know who pronounces cumin like he’s afraid of it. One is my deputy, who has a daughter named after a month. They all smell like sugar sometimes, because we all smell like sugar now. The bakery has been running its mixers through the night For Morale. I didn’t write them. I have other sins I will cop to.”

“Who chose me,” he asked. “Not in a cosmic way. In a paperwork way. Who wrote my name under TALENT. Who twisted the knives into props and my body into a card in a Rolodex.”

She lifted her shoulders and let them fall, a little. “Ten hands and none. The city knows your face now. Monkeys know it. People who hate the city know it. People who love it know it. When a ritual wants to be born, it shops for a midwife with a mouth that looks like it could say the word no and then fail to. You were available. You were brave in the way careful men are brave. You had a sister. Someone wrote your name because their hand had to write a name, and because yours sat up straight on the line. I am sorry for that, which is a small apology in a room full of small apologies.”

He didn’t forgive her, and he did, because forgiveness now was a thing you kept in a jar and spread thin. The monkeys outside on the telephone wire imitated the coffee machine until the barista went out and clapped at them and they clapped back and everyone laughed and then looked down because laughing had started to feel like something you should ask permission to do.

They did the rite again a week later, because a transformer blew in the north and the rolling blackouts moved like a rumor through the grid and a truck stalled on a ramp and a man in a booth somewhere thought of his children in beds and called a number he had written on the back of a paycheck stub. They hid the second rite inside a street fair so the logistics could blend with the sausages, and that made it worse and better. Some people choked on both and blamed the other. A trombone played a song about famine. A woman danced a dance she had learned on an island where the droughts had faces. A monkey put two pieces of scrip over its eyes and declared itself a prophetic accountant and fell off a trash can with a dignity you could not teach. The three hours came, and the three hours went, and again the city did not snow the wrong snow.

After, in the little midnight, a troop waited outside his door in a huddle that might have been ominous and might have been family. The bandaged capuchin from the tram sat on the stoop with a solemnity that made it look briefly human in a way that hurt. It patted the step next to it so hard the dust rose. It was almost too smooth. He knew enough about the city to distrust clean. The capuchin with the bandage saw him first because the world owed him that moment. The monkey moved like the small version of mercy and put its hand on the boy’s wrist with a gentleness that made the wrist remember it belonged to someone who had once held a spoon. The boy looked down and the capuchin looked up and they both looked sideways where a man with a municipal badge had stood on a landing and read a notice. The boy put the bottle back. The capuchin took the boy’s hood and pulled it off, which is the monkey way of shaving a head. The crowd put out the breath it had been holding and then took another.

When it was over, the Cultural Affairs woman adjusted the note she had written to herself about the timing of goats. The mayor went home and sat on the edge of his bed and looked at his feet until the alarm clock, which had been set because the city requires a man with a title to observe the morning, told him to stand. Lark went back to his office and laid his hands on the bone stick and felt for a splinter and found none. Hart went to a bar that had become a room where guilt performed itself on ice and told a joke that made three men swear they would stop hating him and then left without saying goodnight because some kinds of happiness must be managed alone. Rory went home with his mother and cut a version of the night that did not have Ephraim in it at all and sent it to a list of addresses with the subject line Watch This To Learn A Mouth. Miriam lay on her bed and cried without letting her throat make a sound because some sounds are owed to different days. The mandrill slept on a roof curled around a heat vent like a poor god and dreamed of a river that speaks.

Ephraim counted. He counted trucks. He counted the breaths that had been taken and were now scattered in lungs and along the river, in the goats’ bellies, in the bowl with its rim salt-bitter on the tongue. He counted the futures he had bought and the ones he had not yet been asked to save. He counted the days until a fortnight. He counted the letters in the word components and the letters in the word breath and tried to accept that they were not the same and never would be. He put his head on his ledger and listened for a heartbeat and found a rustle that could be paper or could be a small animal settling. He closed his eyes because morning had declared itself and because men like him do not sleep; they adjourn.

The morning came with the small cruelty of details. The plant reported the gauges in the green and the engineer with the stutter sent a message that said Thank and then stopped because the word you is heavy and he had no one to lift it to. The Ritual Advisory Council issued a statement denying it existed and praising the goats for their service to public morale. The paper ran a headline that had been designed the day before and tweaked at dawn: Ledger Drowned; City Breathes. The SENSEFUL STREETS group put out a poster with a goat drawn badly and a speech bubble that said Accounting Is For Carnivores. A troupe of spider monkeys demonstrated, under a traffic light that had given up, how to cut paper without cutting fingers and the fifth monkey bled anyway and laughed because the city required it.

At noon, the sugar letter arrived not at his apartment, not at the office, but in the hands of the capuchin on the tram. The monkey did not joke. It put the paper into Ephraim’s hand with a dead seriousness that felt like a ceremony. He unfolded it because you cannot refuse an oar when you are in water. The hand was the same careful hand, the ink the same cheap kind. It said, in a smaller, more cramped line, We are not satisfied with paper and goats. This is large arithmetic. The thing in the south is greedy. The bright snow is a clause you do not control. In fourteen nights, the winter comes if the appetite is not met. It smelled not of sugar but of ash, and the ash tasted, when he licked his finger and touched it, like the inside of a matchbook.

“What do we do,” the capuchin asked, as if it were begging him to say something human. “Who do we bite if biting does not fix the sky.”

“We buy more time,” he said, because a man in his job ends every sentence that way. “We do not let them put a mouth on the wrong thing. We keep the bridges open. We breathe until the numbers change. We ask the river to help and we give it everything we have that is not a boy.”

“Numbers are bones,” the capuchin said solemnly, as if remembering something he had learned from a woman with a scarf and a boy with blue hair. “We can throw bones to dogs and the dogs will be happy. We cannot throw bones to winter. Winter wants houses.”

He nodded. The tram swayed. The girl with the calculus book underlined something with a pencil that had lost its eraser and then looked out the window at a sign where someone had painted over the word STOP with the words KEEP BREATHING. He wrote the last line of the sugar letter into his pocket ledger because you must write down the words that try to command you so that they are subject to a list. He closed the book and put his hand over it like a lid because some days you give your stomach a little win and pretend it is a strategy.

That night, when he unlocked his door, there was a smell he could not place. It was not gas, it was not bread, it was not the candle from a woman who wielded theater like a wrench. It was a sweetness that had gone bad without spoiling. He followed it down the hall and found the refrigerator ajar. Inside, where he had been keeping the notes chilled like fish you swear you will not cook, there was no paper. There was a hole in the frost where paper edges had been. There was a single olive he had not put there. He touched the olive with his forefinger. It had a bite gone from it. On the inside of the refrigerator door, someone had drawn a mouth with a marker in the wrong hand. The mouth had a tongue. The tongue extended, as jokes sometimes do, too far. He shut the door and the bulb went dark and he stood with his hand on the handle and decided, again, that he would not decide today. He would decide tomorrow, which is to say he would have to decide tonight in secret and hope morning would be fooled.

On his chair, someone had left a book. It was the old kind, the smell of a basement and a church and a stack of winter sweaters. The title had rubbed off except for the word Accounts. Inside, on the first page, in a grandmother hand, a sentence: If we must count, we will count with our mouths closed. He sat with it and the night annoyed the window and somewhere a monkey laughed and somewhere a man wept and somewhere a machine thought it would be a beautiful thing to break. He closed his own mouth and held his breath until his chest said please and then he let it out slowly and wrote the number one on the blank next page without ink. He pressed so hard the paper dented, which is one way a city survives.Chapter 10

He woke in the thin light to the smell the refrigerator had left behind, a sweetness turned cynical, and opened the door as if he might catch the culprit before it had a chance to choose a different home. The notes were gone, the olive with the bite still sat in its ridiculous solitude, and the drawn mouth on the inside door looked smug in the way that only ink can look when it thinks it has made a point. He wiped the marker mouth away with the rough side of a sponge and thought of the phrase clean slate and how it never once in his life had meant clean. He made coffee the way a man fortifies himself for a conversation he cannot win, pressed his thumb into the dent he had written on his own page the night before, and felt how the paper fought back gently, not a refusal so much as a reminder that even fibrous things have a spine.

Hart let himself into the office without knocking, which had become his way of loving people in a crisis, and stood by the window with his tie looped once and then given up on, as if it were a sentence that had found it had said enough. “We have twelve days,” he said without preface, as if they were both mid-prayer and had forgotten to fold their hands. “We have trucks that think they are shy and a plant that wants lullabies and a Council that has translated appetite into font size. We have bridges that remember what men with chains were for.” He slapped a paper on the desk that had been printed with a municipal seriousness that tried to make itself appear inevitable. “Epsilon, manual. Darla blessed it with her highlighter. She found you the names of the men who still teach chains to listen. They keep the keys in a locker labeled ‘Mascots’ because the city is embarrassed by muscle.”

The GIS analyst called on a channel so quiet it sounded as if she were phoning through cloth. “I taught the map a new word,” she said. “Theta. The overlay insists on turning the vanishing tooth into a mouth again on nights when our power lines dream of their childhood. 999 Cherry’s ghost is back, not as a building but as a route. The overlay says Bright Bridges Temporary will run a convoy through the cannery at the hour of doubt. They renamed the truck icon ‘festival.’ It’s a whim and a lie and a plan.” She mailed him the picture and he watched the gray block ghost in and out, learned its rhythm, counted the intervals the way a woman counts contractions when she wants time to behave.

Lark arrived with a rabbit-warren of rolled paper and the bone tally like a wand he had refused a job in a children’s movie to keep. He set the maps on the desk and weighed their corners with staplers because scholars are the only men left who have weights handy. “Attestations moved out of the churchy spaces,” he said with a cheer he refused to name grief. “We’ve got breath on paper from nine wards and a stray from the airport. Teens are breathing on the backs of their math homework because they like the wrongness. They’re turning the breath page over to see the ghost of their equations and they think that’s magic. It is, a little. Rory’s piece taught them a mouth. They are doing it without the music sometimes and sometimes with, and the monkeys are watching and trying the count on their fingers and pretending they don’t care when the number five licks their brain.” He held up a page dented with a hundred patient exhales and said very softly, to himself, “That ought to be worth a chain.”

At the plant the engineer with the stutter met him with a spoon he had wrapped in a paper towel as if it were an heirloom. “They put gum on the valve,” he said, the g of gum heavy, and Ephraim thought of boys in alleys and wives with black aprons and monkeys with nothing to do and all of the city’s fingers pressed into mistakes. “I don’t know who. I don’t ask. I scraped it with this. My mother said never throw away a spoon that fits your hand. I might be arrested for saying it, but I want you to have it.” The spoon’s bowl had a notch worn by soup and by time. It felt like a tongue trying to make a number better by tasting it. He slid it into his jacket pocket with a care that was not for metal but for the stories that choose to hitch a ride there.

The Cultural Affairs woman asked for a walk by the river and did not light a candle. “Be practical,” she said, and then laughed at herself because she sounded like a person who sells pillows. “My deputy—June—put ash on the notes with a finger she dipped in an old tin I keep on my desk for emergencies and ghosts. She wrote them on my paper with my pen and wept about you in the bathroom because she was ashamed of doing the thing she thought would save the city. She is not a villain. She is an employee with a daughter named May, and the world told her that if you do not make the ritual strong you get winter for dessert.” The apology sat between them like a dog that had learned it was allowed on furniture now. “I removed her from the line where words turn to summonses,” she added. “I did not fire her because the city might need later the kind of woman who can smell when the floor is going to give.”

“What does Theta buy,” he asked. He watched a cormorant go under as if it had seen a ledger in the water it needed to balance.

“Leverage,” she said, adjusting her scarf as if she could arrange her soul with wool. “Insurers hold it. A contractor whose trucks have cherries on them holds it. A lobbyist who can make the word contingency sound like a meal holds it. Theta is a club over our head. Every hour we buy by making a meal out of paper, they will try to sell back to us at markup. We’re paying an interest rate in fear. The clause isn’t a law. It’s a mood at a conference table. I’m saying this out loud because we are running out of time to tell the truth in full sentences.”

He went to Miriam for the part of this kind of day where you allow something to be obvious in front of someone who won’t sell it. She had pulled the curtains half-closed so the apartment looked like a memory of itself. “Irreversible,” she said, serving him a pear on a plate that had belonged to their grandmother so old it had wood in it. “The mandrill asked for something we can’t walk back. I thought of shaving my head and decided I’m not sentimental about hair in that direction. I thought of taking the sign off the countinghouse and writing museum in chalk so it could be erased. I thought of writing uncle on the ground outside the Hall and rubbing it out with my heel until the word cried. Then I thought of olive pits, which do a sneaky thing with permanence. You eat the olive. You spit the pit. The pit lingers on the ground making promises. I want to make a pit with the city. Something we plant.” She stabbed the pear with her knife in a way that made the pear feel like victory and then pulled back because she saw his face. “We could shut a lane that leads to the cannery forever and make it a strip of garden,” she said more gently. “A literal barrier between the pallets and the street. They can’t drive vans through a trellis if the trellis holds beans.”

The mandrill held court on a library roof, because monkeys choose their rooms by the quality of ledges, and listened to her cousins’ arguments with a kind of patient boredom that told you she had learned more than you thought from watching committees. The juvenile rhesus, feeling the moon fatten whether or not he believed in it, insisted on eyebrows again with an affection that made his rudeness almost lovely. The chimp rapped his knuckles on the skylight and stared into the reading room where three humans had fallen asleep with newspapers on their faces, and the mandrill said in her old-longshoreman voice that hair wreaths hung at every door would satisfy the old ones for a season if they smelled like dog and if the wreaths were taken to the river after. She said, too, that if anyone cut a girl’s hair without asking, she would bite them on the hand so that the scar would be a reason forever not to do it again. The rhesus nodded solemnly like a page accepting a task, and then, being fifteen in spirit, attempted to steal a bookmark from a man below and failed twice and then succeeded once and felt the holy thrill of trivial theft.

They built a list and then they built a practice. Darla printed, stamped, collated, and put her lipstick on with a steadiness that made all the red in the city look like a promise and not a threat. She made “breath cards” that were not cards, just paper heavy enough to take a fingernail, and the fingernail left a clear mark that no one could erase without cutting the page. She assigned runners to the bridges and scheduled calls as if scheduling were prayer. Hart found the goat man leaning on a fence talking softly to an animal who did not need human words and made him promise three times that he would accept apples and not ask for changes in the law as payment. The goat man, whose name was Salim and who owned two pairs of socks that had learned to love mud, agreed to bring the cleanest, hungriest mouths in the city to the Hall for a second contract of silence.

The night sent an emissary to him in the form of a woman sitting on the cannery steps with her shoes off and her stockings rolled around her ankles like two different regrets. June, the deputy, did not stand when he stopped. She offered him a cigarette she did not light as if she were making a joke for a movie that liked to show competence as ruin. “I’m not sorry enough,” she said plainly. “I wrote the notes because in every meeting I sat in men made euphemisms until I wanted to drag my face on carpet. I thought if I put the fear in pretty, you’d obey the pretty. It worked and it didn’t. It always works and it never does. I’m fired in the way that keeps my health insurance, which is how this city breaks your heart without technically doing anything wrong.” She lifted her head. “Theta isn’t just a clause. It’s a specific mischief. There are three warehouses with tanks that would behave like a bad winter if they were convinced it was their time. Two are guarded. One is watched by a man who plays cards with our enemies. He’s not a villain either. He’s lonely.” She slid him a list folded so tight he needed his thumbnail to pry it open. “There is so much to guard that we will fail. There is, maybe, just enough to love that the failure will not be the kind that steals breath. Do not forgive me now. I don’t want to write that scene.”

On the last day before the moon did its old theater, the city performed a blasphemous rehearsal. Powder fell from a rooftop along a block in the Ward with the broken clock, tossed from five-gallon buckets by boys who had been promised a hardness by a man on a phone who had never once stood and watched a sky remember how to behave. The powder wreathed the block and tongues found it the way tongues find worry. The monkeys shrieked and then acted sick and then laughed and then were still, which was the strangest part. Hydrants were opened by men who had pulled their whole lives and watched the pretend ash turn to paste that never forgot its baptism. A goat wandered in from a lot and licked the paste with a look of someone willing to try any food once. The powder turned the goat’s chin gray. The goat shook its head, sneezed, and trotted away with an air of disappointment that read like an editorial. The men with the buckets watched their theater melt and did not clap. The Cultural Affairs woman arrived with a mop and the mayor with a rolled-up plan he forgot to unfurl and the mandrill with her jaw tight. “You think snow is cheap,” she said to no one and everyone. “Wait until you have to sweep.” Ephraim wrote in his ledger: practice panic, sweep, kebab for the men who opened the valves, no notes.

Harvest night came dressed as itself. The moon had the confidence of an elder who has outlived everybody’s taste. The Hall of Balances smelled like unwashed wool and ink. The wreath on the door looked foolish until it didn’t. The bowl glared, which is a trick bowls know. The ledger lay open to the part where deceit narrows like a river into usable pain. The goat man stood by with his hand on his favorite’s head, and the favorite looked at him with a devotion so stupid it could save a family from a fire. The bridges waited for chains and hands. Public Works checked the manual cranks with banana fingers in gloves. The monkeys took their places in different trees than last time as if to test the city’s reflexes.

They did not speak the boy’s name. They did not even say boy. The mayor said ledger and saw that nobody flinched and then said ledger again softly as if it were a lullaby his mother might have hummed if the world had been something else. Ephraim cut the lines and laid them in the bowl. Each strip of paper seemed to say please, and he could not tell if the paper begged to be eaten or to be spared the indignity of metaphor. Miriam stood in the back with olives and made a face like a gate that keeps. Lark made the cross of someone else’s religion over the bone tally and told it under his breath that it was doing very well. The mandrill watched and breathed only when the chimp breathed, as if to braid the act into a rope that might hold more than animal.

The powder-droppers, having been humiliated by hydrants, tried again in a subtler place, the roof of the post office where the city hides the letters that hurt. The capuchin who had stolen a stapler days before used it to hit the elbow of the boy about to spill and said, in a tone of casual companionship, “Don’t.” The boy’s face did the quick arithmetic of dignity; he looked at the city, the moon, his own hand, and then he put the bucket down and sat with his legs over the edge so that everyone who looked up had to consider human ankles. It was not heroism. It was posture re-taught.

When the bowl was full enough that the rim tasted like kale, they carried it out. A woman tripped and a man caught her under the elbow and she kissed him without thinking as if luck had to be thanked with mouth. The goats ate the names they were given and let the rest go river. Chains clanked on three bridges and the fourth refused because it had pride and a bad hinge, and four men with hands like history pulled anyway while a troop of rhesus threw their bodies on the chain and felt a pleasure that the city could have used for different things if it had had the time. South, the plant clicked its clicks and the engineer counted, and a figure on a walkway at Warehouse Three, the one with the lonely man, put his phone away and lit a cigarette instead and told himself a story about his daughter in another place and the time he would tell her a story that made him look like a man.

In the Hall someone whispered nephew because there is always a person who insists on touching a hot stove, and the mandrill flicked her ear and a silence fell so sudden it felt like a new weather. The word hung a second and then died the way small fires die when rain picks a neighborhood to love. Hart laughed once under his breath as if he had seen an old joke learn manners. Darla distributed breath cards and told people sternly where to put their nail, and people obeyed because the sternness was full of love and because she had a face the city had agreed not to lie to. The Cultural Affairs woman watched the juvenile rhesus mouth the word ledger and shook like a girl who had rescued a dog from a road and was only now allowed to feel it.

The counter-rite played itself under a streetlight four blocks away, plastic knifery and a poster of a boy borrowed from somewhere that had nothing to do with this city. The crowd did not boo. It turned and walked and the knives fell with the dignity of toys abandoned by toddlers. The men who had brought the knives cried because they had not planned for a script without an ending. Rory filmed them with a gentleness that had edges, and later cut it into the piece that would make people in other cities stop pretending they have no cousins.

After the bowl and the goats and the breath there was a bench. He sat on it because he could feel the shape of himself and it needed a flat thing. The capuchin sat beside him and handed him back the spoon he had forgotten he’d given it, the engineer’s spoon, wrapped again in the paper towel because the monkey had learned etiquette and was proud of knowing where to put its paws. “Your sister’s olives were better tonight,” the capuchin said, and wiped its nose with the back of its hand like a child who has been told twelve times to use a napkin. “I bit two men who said they wanted to do a prank and they agreed they did not. I will not bite as a hobby. I will bite as a craft. Tell your goats they did theater without lying.”

He did not go home because home had the smell of refrigerator regret. He went to the river for a while and watched the skin of the water accept and deny and accept. The moon cupped its light the way a waitress brings coffee. The city made the sound cities make when large things are done and no one died: the kind of cheering you only let the air do for you. The Cultural Affairs woman appeared like a moral at the end of a story told by someone too tired for point and sat without asking if the bench had room. “June left a note,” she said. “No sugar. She wrote in pencil, hard, so it left a valley. It said: I will stop making it worse. It said: If you need me to carry boxes in the rain I can do that and never once choose a noun. I like her again because she is a person. I will tell her daughter that her mother once fed a goat an ugly word and watched it disappear.”

He slept late the next morning and woke to the particular quiet of a city putting itself back on its own lap. The plant’s numbers texted themselves in polite green. The bridges were open, tasting their own usefulness like a metal tongue saying grace. The goat man sent a photo of his animals in a lot under a billboard that used to sell vacations and now just sold sky, their mouths still working with dream. SENSEFUL STREETS put out a poster that corrected its goat and called the rite bourgeois, a word that had lost all meaning in the year and was now just a sound you made when your mouth wanted to feel French. The mayor said in front of microphones that the Rite Advisory Council did not exist and that its meeting was postponed to a date that would be announced when the moon had learned to mind its own business.

At Kettle & Hart, the monkeys had braided ribbons out of the substitute scrip and were using them to try to tow a chair across the floor. Darla put a hand to her mouth as if to hide a spell and then declared loudly that if anyone put their teeth on her copier she would put their head in a file drawer, and four rhesus mimed decapitation and then apologized without being asked. Hart had drawn a goat on his whiteboard and given it a speech bubble that said Pay Your Debts to Rivers. He stood with his shoes off again and said, “You stole time and fed it to something that forgot to be angry at you. That’s a trick. Don’t do it again unless you have to.”

On the tram a woman read a story to a boy with a winter hat in a month that had no right to need hats yet. He watched her mouth shape ledger with more care than he would have thought a stranger had for his private nouns. The capuchin slept, head on his shoe, like a dog with nothing to prove. When he reached his door there was no letter. He opened the refrigerator anyway and there, where the notes had been, was a bowl of olives wrapped in waxed paper with a note in Miriam’s hand that said: You still have a mouth. He stood a long time with the door open tasting the cold and the brine and the possibility that abstaining had bought him something more than just a few hours of trucks. He shut the door not with triumph but with the carefulness of a man who knows he will be asked again and wants to be ready to be the same man twice if he can manage it. He took out his ledger and, with the spoon’s bowl held to the page like a tracer, impressed, with no ink at all, a second number beside the first, and then a third, because sometimes the only way to teach your hands a mercy is to let them count how many times they have chosen not to be knives.

On the morning the monkeys learned how to make a siren out of a traffic cone, Ephraim Cole counted twenty-seven of them on the tram. The driver didn’t stop them; the driver never stopped them anymore. A capuchin with a bandaged ear dangled from the rubber strap above Ephraim’s head and spit a single sunflower seed onto the calculus text of a high school girl. The capuchin kept one eye on Ephraim’s briefcase. They all did that now, like the case might open and exhale a roast chicken or a grenade.

“Morning, pen-chewer,” the bandaged one said, voice like a pipe scraped by a wire. He had learned Ephraim’s face two months ago, after the audit board forced the City to publish the monkey tickets and fines; it was still strange to be famous to the wrong species.

“Good morning,” Ephraim said, because he never could carve a new habit for himself. Courtesy had calcified around him into a shape like a second skin, the shape of a compliant man in a tilted city.

“Drop that box,” the monkey said, then laughed and clapped at its own joke like a cymbalist. “You drop it, we catch it, you cry.”

“I won’t drop it,” Ephraim said. The girl with the calculus text lifted her book and wiped the sunflower seed away. The driver let the tram sigh through an intersection where four macaques in orange construction vests waved plastic paddles and made obscene faces at the buses. One of the vest monkeys had a whistle; he alternated between a regulation no-noise and a ululated wolf-cry that made the pigeons on the wires throw themselves into the morning like a blanket tossed off a bed.

Ephraim was forty-seven years old, unmarried, with a mortgage he despised and a sister who still loved him in a way that flummoxed him. He kept his hair short because monkeys pulled hair when they were angry. He had a precise face, a precise way of walking, and a precise belief that numbers were bones and we could look through them to see the body that had walked there before. He worked at Kettle & Hart, a firm known for making the ungovernable governable until the monkeys moved in and declared governance a snack.

As the tram eased into St. Alabaster’s Square, a troop of vervets jogged alongside, their tails flying like banners. One—smaller, with a burn scar like a coin on its shoulder—threw a handful of gravel at the windows. “Audit this!” the small one shouted, and then, in falsetto, “We appreciate your service!” The others cackled and slapped one another’s back as if applause could be traded. The bandaged capuchin tugged at the strap until the rubber groaned.

“You’re late,” it said. “You’re late, numbers, numbers, numbers. Where’s your tail? I have one.” It twitched its little hook to demonstrate.

“I’m not late,” Ephraim said, although he was ten minutes behind, and he hated himself for the need to correct the statement. “And I don’t chew pens.”

“Oh? You chew little boys?” Another cymbal-clap. A murmur from the humans in the car. Ephraim’s briefcase weighed a mile. The capuchin stuck its tongue out, pale and repulsive and weirdly human at the edges. “Little boy uncle. Uncle eats, uncle eats.”

“Stop,” the girl with the textbook said. Her voice had that end-of-argument tone certain teenagers carry like an extra rib. “You’re disgusting.”

“We’re art,” the monkey said, and slid back out the open window as the tram doors peeled open. It was gone into the chrome and sun and diesel.

On the platform, a troupe of monkeys had stacked crates and were attempting to stand on each other’s shoulders to reach a banner that read MONKEYS FOR SENSEFUL STREETS. The sign had been paid for by the Chamber of Commerce as a friendly show of support. Last week’s Chamber president resigned with a rash. The crates trembled. A rhesus monkey at the bottom groaned and barfed onto the pavement. The one above him laughed, poked the vomit with a pencil, and wrote something obscene with it that looked, somehow, a little like Ephraim’s name.

Familiar gooseflesh climbed Ephraim’s arms as he considered turning back for home, for the toasted rye he had left on the counter and the dome of quiet around his apartment above the bakery. But he had an appointment. And also—though he hardly said it even to himself—it felt like quitting when people were watching. He kept moving, kept his briefcase tucked under his elbow like a heart he didn’t want to hand back.

Kettle & Hart occupied the tenth and eleventh floors of the Gray Tower, although “occupied” was inaccurate: somewhere between city policy and monkey preference, the tenth floor had become a playground. No one could think why. The monkeys didn’t work there; they didn’t sleep there. They only hung from the fluorescent light fixtures and yowled in tight harmonies that made interns cry. They dipped their paws in the fish tank and threw guppies at the arrow plants. Someone had brought a swing—someone had affixed the swing to the load-bearing crossbeam. It creaked. The building inspectors signaled a complaint, but the complaint was caught and chewed on by a gang of spider monkeys who ate vowels like potato chips.

“Morning, Mr. Cole,” said Darla, the receptionist, as he stepped off the elevator into the lobby on eleven. She was dressed in a blouse the color of clean money, the exact tint of cash that hadn’t thought about itself enough to be dirty.

“Morning,” he said. He glanced at the glass—monkeys’ faces were smeared into the lobby windows like thumbprints on a mirror. One made a heart with its hands when he looked. Another threw a rock.

Darla slid him a folder across the counter. “The mayor’s office called. Your methods are ‘too revealing’? They’d like you to use fewer colors.” Her mouth didn’t change shape as she said it.

He opened the folder. Inside there was a memo with the City seal and the subheading Suggestions for Softer Accounting. He had invented those color graphs because they were the only way to make the river of money look like a river. He had been told repeatedly that citizens liked rivers; rivers were calming. His graphs showed the City’s main channels and the tributaries: a blue torrent down the middle, a green stream for parks, a brown trickle that oozed toward rat control. And off to one side, a new canal that had opened in October, labeled Public Simian Integration Fund. It was a bright yellow that flickered as if someone had set the room on fire.

“Fewer colors,” Ephraim said. He looked up. “We’re bleeding yellow.”

“I’m not supposed to say that,” Darla said. “You’re not supposed to say anything that sounds like that.” She leaned closer. A monkey pressed its face to the glass, cheeks flat, breath spooling a fog. “You remember you’re having lunch with Miriam and Rory.”

“How could I forget,” he said, and instantly felt the guilt that followed repeated tenderness. He liked lunch with his sister. He liked the way his nephew stole the olives. He liked the way the olives looked, too—little green eyeballs in their dish, wet and ridiculous.

He made it to his office with only one interruption, a small troop of monkeys who had discovered his door and had written on it in grease pencil: FRIED ACCOUNTANT. They had drawn a crude pan. He wiped the drawing away with the sleeve of his jacket and made a mental note to stop making mental notes. It was exhausting to owe himself so much.

He loved his office still: the parquet floor stared back at him with quiet pattern; the books smelled like paper instead of panic. He opened his laptop and typed his password: abacus462!—a gentle insult to himself—and the spreadsheet bloomed like a forewarned flower.

Six months of figures. Ticketing revenue down. Banana import tax up. Gasoline spent on chases involving motorcycle-riding macaques: up, up, uP. A curious line item from the Department of Cultural Affairs called Interprimatic Reparations: ongoing. He drilled into it. Contractor names. A nonprofit named Bright Bridges run out of an address that didn’t exist: 999 Cherry Road. A series of five payments to something called Uncle’s Tithe Fund. He made a fist in the air like a conductor with no orchestra. He breathed. He looked. The column said the payments had been listed not as expenses but as swaps. Assets for assets. City for time.

He called up the PDF of the original agreement that had been signed in that televised ceremony in the courthouse rotunda, the one where a female mandrill in a satin jacket had licked the microphone and the mayor had laughed like a man falling through a glass table. Reconciliation Accord, the document said. He typed a search for “tithe.” Nothing. But the ledger kept the unsayable like a smuggled spoon.

“Cole,” said a voice from his doorway. He turned. Mr. Hart himself leaned there like a rakish uncle in a play, a tie dangling, a grin that had browned like a banana. He was a good man in the way that a boat can be good in a storm and useless in dock.

“Good morning,” Ephraim said.

“Color trouble,” Hart said, and whistled through his teeth. “Don’t soften for them. Not yet.” He stepped into the office, hip bumped a plant, didn’t notice. “Going to the museum tonight?”

“What museum.”

“Countinghouse Museum? Lark’s talk. ‘Numerics in the Age of Primate Civility.’ He’s going to say something he shouldn’t. He hinted. He can’t stop hinting, that man. I figure someone has to clap loudly.” Hart peered at the screen. He hummed a C. “Uncle’s Tithe Fund. That’s new.”

“You’ve seen it?”

“I’ve seen everything,” Hart said, then spread his hands. “But I don’t know how to see this. There’s a rumor the monkeys want to make the uncle the new father.”

“What?”

Hart inclined his head. “It doesn’t make sense, Cole. You’re right. This whole thing is cross-eyed. But—” He stopped, glanced out the glass wall toward the monkeys who had found their reflections and were making love to them. “Everything makes sense to someone.”

“I don’t like that someone,” Ephraim said. “I don’t like that he’s in my spreadsheet.”

Hart laughed. “Lunch with Miriam?” He had a way of asking questions he already knew the answers to that made you forgive him for asking.

“I’m going,” Ephraim said.

“Good. Eat good food. It might get scarce when the scooters run out of gas.” Hart’s face twitched. “If the monkeys start siphoning fuel, it’s all over.”

“They don’t need fuel,” Ephraim said. “They need an audience.”

“Amen,” Hart said. He clapped him on the shoulder and left a faint hair on his sleeve. Ephraim plucked it off as if it might deliver a surprise stinger.

He worked an hour. He took notes. He made a small chart with fewer colors—a grayscale puddle that told the truth with a whisper. He printed it and slid it into a manila folder and wrote in block letters: TRUTH BUT QUIET. He shut his laptop. He touched his forehead to the cool glass and watched a juvenile monkey investigate a stapler like a bomb. The city had felt like this before, he thought, once long ago when he had been a boy and his mother had taught him to add his change at the grocery store. That was the day he’d realized that sometimes the numbers came up wrong because someone had taken something. He had been seven; he had cried. His mother had looked around and said, “Shh. Not so loud. There are other kinds of wrong to worry about.”

At twenty to twelve he walked to Café Hav, where the tables on the sidewalk had been fitted with spring-loaded lids to discourage theft. The lids did nothing but make the compliments louder when they worked. Miriam was already there, hair tucked into a scarf, hands wrapped around a glass of water like it was a small animal she meant to teach a trick. He loved her forehead most: the wide plain of it, the place where she stored her thoughts. Her son—his nephew—Rory—sat opposite, chin in hand, the other hand flicking through videos on his phone. He had dyed his hair a shade of blue that wasn’t a color but a refusal. He looked up, saw Ephraim, and managed a smile that felt like an eclipse: a bright circle borrowed from the dark.

“You’re late,” Miriam said, and then kissed his cheek. “I’ve ordered olives. We have a window of time.”

“Before what?” Ephraim asked.

“Before they remember they like them,” she said. She nodded toward a pair of monkeys crouching on the fire escape above, smoking cigarettes they had stolen from the bus depot. The cigarettes made them cough; the coughing made them laugh. Everything that hurt made them louder.

“Hi, Uncle E,” Rory said. “I took a video of a gibbon putting Mayor Henley’s hat in a urinal. It’s art.”

“You sound like them,” Ephraim said, and immediately regretted it.

“Not like them,” Rory said softly. He flicked through his phone. “They’re dirty poets.” He lifted the device so Ephraim could see: there was the mayor, face spanked with sweat, looking up as a long-limbed gray creature lowered the hat into a bowl that had not been cleaned since the last three parades.

“They learned it from us,” Miriam said. “They learn everything from us. That’s the problem—it’s all a mirror. I just wish the mirror was clean.”

Ephraim sat. The waiter brought olives, a plate of fried anchovies, and bread with a rind like a crusted planet. They ate first—always eat first, Miriam had taught him—because conversation could be stolen but food could only be taken from you one bite at a time, and that took time.

“How’s school,” he asked Rory, so he could pretend the world was normal. “Any good teachers.”

“Mr. Lark is my favorite,” Rory said.

“The museum one?” Ephraim asked.

“Adjunct,” Rory said with the sadness of someone who had learned too soon how words could make a ladder and also a cage. “He’s teaching a class on Counting Rituals. He says before we wrote numbers we had to eat a number.”

“Eat a number,” Miriam said. “I love that nonsense.”

“It’s not nonsense,” Rory said, and looked at Ephraim for allyhood. “He says you can’t hold a thing you don’t recognize. You have to put it in your mouth to know it. Infants. Tribes. Banks.” He tore a piece of bread and ate it, eyes closed. “He says there was a ceremony, very old, where the man who kept the ledger, to inoculate the village against loss, had to—” He stopped, looked at his mother, and then said quickly, “It’s a silly story.”

“Tell it,” Miriam said, mouth full.

“He had to eat his kin,” Rory said.

Ephraim’s fork paused midair. He set it down. “Which kin.”

“Nephew,” Rory said. He didn’t smile. He didn’t look up. “It’s stupid. It was a metaphor. Mr. Lark loves metaphors. He’s like a metaphor with tenure.”

“Adjuncts don’t have tenure,” Miriam said. “Also don’t say nephew. It tastes strange.”

“It tasted strange in class too,” Rory said, and then he looked at his uncle, really looked, as if looking was a new thing one might try between mouthfuls of fish. “You okay?”

“I’m fine,” Ephraim said. “It’s a story. We have a stack of them. The monkeys like to climb them.”

Rory laughed. Miriam rolled an olive across the table to him. He caught it with a hand he didn’t know he trusted yet. Ephraim felt something cold drift through him like a cloud across a field, a shadow with a square edge. He drank water.

“It’s not your job to fix the city,” Miriam said later, when they were waiting for coffee. “You hear me? We all have two hands. If you spend both on the wheel, you don’t have any left to drink your coffee.”

“You know there’s a tithe,” he said, because the word had been rattling around his ribs since he’d seen it. “In the records. An Uncle’s Tithe.”

Miriam’s eyes narrowed. She was good at narrowing. “That’s a knot I don’t want to pick. Let’s eat our pastries.”

They did. The coffee was a little bitter, in the way things are bitter when you want them to be sweet. A young macaque across the street tried to steal the salt shaker from the table of an elderly man; when the old man moved to block, the macaque bit his knuckle and then put its hand to its mouth and made exaggerated gagging faces as if he had fed it poison. Two other monkeys imitated the gag. They laughed. The old man stared at his hand like it had turned into a piece of the moon. He stowed it in his lap and would not take it out again.

Ephraim walked back to the office through a gaggle of them. One looked at his shoes and said, “Nice feet, uncle.” Another threw him a puck of chewed gum, pink and wet. The world smelled like exhaust and old fruit. He missed the smell of snow, the way it had used to smell when he was young and the world had stopped for a minute and then started again with good intentions.

When he sat again, he’d been gone two hours. Two new messages: one from the mayor’s assistant, explaining how color had feelings; one from the Countinghouse Museum, a bland invitation to Lark’s talk with a line at the bottom that had been pasted in crooked: bring a friend or bring none. We are happy with your choice. The font was wrong. When he printed it, the letters flickered as if heat were rising off them.

At five he went. He told Darla he’d bring her back a pin from the museum shop. She told him to bring her back a piece of good news, and then made the sign against the evil eye her grandmother had given her for free. The monkeys followed him for six blocks, hooting and making little kissing sounds, and then peeled off at the intersection where an ice cream truck had learned that playing calliope music would now be answered with rocks.

Countinghouse stood with its back to the river, a square building with a frieze of coins around the top. The glass doors were scummed with monkey prints. Inside, the guards had been given whistles, and when a macaque tried to slide in on a local boy’s heels, the guards blew so hard their cheeks fluttered like flags. The macaque laughed and mimed blowing into an invisible whistle until a third guard kissed him on the head, which somehow worked and the macaque left.

“Mr. Cole,” said a voice. Professor Lark materialized like a thesis from behind a column. Thin as a line, hair that had lost interest in obeying gravity, a tie printed with little numbers at play. “I’m sorry about the tram. It’s a chorus these days.”

“I had sardines for lunch,” Ephraim said, a bit too quickly. “What’s a tithe.”

Lark blinked. “You didn’t say hello.”

“I said it in my heart. What’s a tithe.”

Lark’s mouth twisted. “A little bit of sacrifice formalized into the ledger so that you can look at it without bleeding.”

“So you bleed and then you record it,” Ephraim said.

“You record it and therefore you can bleed,” Lark said, not unkindly. “Come inside. I will tell you something during the Q&A that will make three donors leave. I can’t help it.”

They stood through Lark’s talk with fifty other citizens—fewer than before, Ephraim noted, although more than an English department reading. The monkey presence was there, too: small furry shapes on rafters, a hand dipping into a purse, a whispered slur like a draught in winter. Lark spoke about the earliest tallies, about knotted cords and burnt marks on bone. He showed an image of a ledger from a village nobody wanted to admit they came from, a book that had been kept under a floorboard in a hut that had been moved from the valley to a living room to a display.

“The book doesn’t say it,” Lark said, and the lights deepened around his body. “The book doesn’t write the part that makes you sick. The book keeps you from throwing up. It says grain. It says wheat. It says goats. It says winter. It says aunt. It says tree. It says nephew.” He paused. He was dramatic. He didn’t need props. “But the elders did not do what we do with the nephew. They didn’t make him a scholarship. They didn’t give him to marriage. They—” His mouth did a little grieving thing. He shook his head.

Someone in the back said, as a joke, “They ate him,” and the room rippled. You could almost see the ripple, like heat.

Lark swallowed. “It was not a feast,” he said. “It was a counting. It was not cruelty, in the sense that a cat is cruel to a bird. It was algebra. A thing you hope not to have to do again.”

A monkey from the rafters blew him a kiss and then made a rude suggestion with its finger. Lark bowed toward it, still scholarly. “The world bears the marks of our arithmetic,” he said. “When the sums go mad, the animals correct us.” His eyes found Ephraim’s like a pin into a butterfly. “We thought we could live without a ledger. But we cannot live without the person who holds the ledger.”

On his way down the museum steps, someone pressed a paper into Ephraim’s hand. He didn’t see the face. The paper crackled like something that had been dried on a radiator. He stuck it into his jacket pocket because his first instinct, after being handed something he didn’t understand, was not to understand it yet. He walked along the river. He looked down into the water and thought of tongues. If you put a number into your mouth, would you learn it? If you put a world?

When he got home—climb the stairs, key stuck in a stubborn lock, the smell of baking sunk into the wood like forgiveness—he took the paper out and unfolded it and saw seven lines of writing in a hand so careful it could have been a mask.

Ephraim Cole. You are the appointed. You will do the killing that saves. The monkeys will jeer. The people will weep. The balance will tilt back away from the bright snow. Eat the boy you love. Eat him before the Harvest Moon. Or all of us will be eaten by the final winter. Please do it clean.

He sat. He put the paper on the table and put a glass of water on top of it as if it might float away. He went to the sink and washed his hands. He washed them until the monkeys outside began to bang on the fire escape and chant, in a nursery rhythm that had kept him company for the last two months: “Uncle’s belly, uncle’s belly, yum yum yum.”

Someone, he thought, was playing with him. He had always been easy to play with; he had had the wrong face for ignoring.

He tore the note in half and then into quarters and then into something like lint. He opened the window and saw the troop on the fire escape. They wore curtains like capes; one smoked a cigarette with the wrong end in its mouth and acted out choking for the others who applauded. “Boo,” said the smallest. “Boo uncle.”

“Go away,” he said, so mild, so mild it made him angry. He shut the window.

He slept badly. Dreams like spreadsheets, cells’ edges cutting into him. He woke at three and there it was again, the idea, the bright and awful clear idea like a sign on a bridge: this is where the road ends. It was stupid, it was offensive, it was impossible. It was also very simple. He hated simple. People used simple like a weapon.

At six, without coffee, he walked the three blocks to Miriam’s. The street was nearly quiet; only a few monkeys out, the early ones, smoking and spitting, scratching their bellies, tossing glass bottles in soft underhand arcs at shop doors. Miriam’s building was patched brick with a climbing vine that the monkeys had used to practice tying knots. He rang. He waited. He rang again. He could hear the radio inside, a voice that read the news with healthy confusion. He could feel the city stretching and then going stiff again in the cold.

“Eph?” Miriam’s voice at the door crack, and then the chain; then her face, hair messy, robe tied in a knot like a coin. “What’s wrong.” It wasn’t a question.

“Nothing,” he said. “I brought pastries. From the shop below my place.”

“You’re a devil,” she said. “Rory’s asleep. He came home late from a screening. Something called A Poem Made of Garbage.”

“I’ve heard of it,” he said, and he had, Rory had told him, and he hadn’t understood. You could see a poem and not understand it. You could eat one and fail to taste it. He had done both.

He sat in their kitchen, which had a table he had swaggered into their life with, a table he had rescued from the curb when a contractor had gone bankrupt and had left furniture in the street like a trail of bones. He liked the table because it could hold weight without telling you about it. Miriam poured coffee. They ate the pastries. The ones with cream had been flattened by the bag; cream oozed slightly out and they used their finger to wipe it up. He thought about tongues again. He thought about numbers. He thought about the way his throat closed.

“What’s the sound of bad news,” Miriam asked, and because they were siblings he said, “Shoes,” and they both laughed. That was what their mother had said the year the factory shut down, when the neighbors filled their SUVs with things they had worked on for half their lives. “Bad news sounds like shoes.” The clatter on the steps, the clatter backwards.

“I have a note,” he said. He didn’t know he was going to say it until it stood in the air between them. “In my pocket. Someone left it at the museum.”

“Do I want to hear it,” she asked.

“No,” he said. “But also you do.” He left the part out about how he had ripped it, and the part about how ripping had done nothing to it. He told her what it said. He told her the words like they had been written on a blackboard behind his eyes. He told her slowly, like the person you love is a fire that you can burn if you go too quickly.

Miriam pressed her thumb hard into the table. He saw the whitish oval where the blood moved away. She was quiet a long time. The radio talked about the monkeys. The radio talked about a ward in the south where a troop had taken over the elementary school and had refused to let the children leave until they had taught the monkeys how to spell filth. The radio used the word unfortunate. The radio said, “Authorities are urging calm,” and then a loud crash, as someone threw something at the radio.

“I hate this story,” Miriam said. “If you told me a different one, I would follow you into it. I would. I would wear whatever costume you told me to. But I can’t. I won’t. Two hundred years ago people did a lot of dirty things and they called it math. The world doesn’t ask you to be a knife.”

“It feels like the world does,” he said. “It has the tone.”

“What are we, then,” she asked, “if not the ones who tilt back? If not the ones who refuse to look at a boy and see an answer.”

He rubbed his face. He wanted to leave so he could stop hurting her with himself. He wanted to stay so whatever came would come while he was there to stand in front of it with his hair and his body and his poor math.

From Rory’s room came a crash. Then a curse. Then silence. Ephraim stood before Miriam could. He had a key to the hallway lock; he didn’t knock. He walked in like family walks in: with his hand up as if a room can be covered like a bird.

Rory sat cross-legged on the floor, surrounded by the spilled guts of his backpack: a camera, two notebooks, a banana with a bite out of it and then another bite out of the peel. He looked up, startled, then laughed, then saw his mother behind Ephraim and reconfigured his face. Ephraim wanted to call the face “honest,” but it was more complicated than that. It was what you put on when you knew the world wanted to suck on your skin.

“What broke,” Miriam asked. Her voice had gone into the tone she saved for nurses and that one uncle who drank the Christmas cards.

“The little tripod,” Rory said. “It was cheap. I bought it with my own money. It’s okay. I’ll use books instead.” He stacked some books. They were about film and about old cities and about how to make a home out of a place that bites.

Ephraim kneeled and set the tripod up and clicked it. It clicked. “A screw,” he said. “Not a break.” He turned the screw with his thumbnail until it obeyed. He wanted to fix everything with thumbnails and not with old words. He wanted to be allowed to do that.

“Thanks,” Rory said. He looked at him as if the thanks were a way to put a coin in a machine. “What’s wrong,” he asked, surprising both of them. “You look like math.”

“I am math,” Ephraim said, because it was easier than saying the other thing. “We’re going to go. I’ll send you that grant link, okay?”

Rory’s eyebrows lifted. “Don’t,” he said softly. “I will apply. But don’t give me a ladder that goes into the wrong house.”

On the way out, Miriam put her hand on Ephraim’s wrist. “We make our own sums,” she said. “We do. No one gets to tell us who is food.”

“I agree,” he said. The words floated like balloons; he tied them to his chair in his mind. “I agree.”

He went to work. He stared at his screen until seven. He solved for x and then for y. He solved for z and then he solved for a little boy with blue hair and a camera and a mother who was not wrong. He did not find a solution that did not put blood in the margins. The monkeys on the other side of the glass had taken to hitting their heads on the window in a steady rhythm. Someone had given them helmets. He did not decide anything because deciding would change the world and he was not ready to end the world yet. The world liked to decide itself.

On the tram home, the bandaged capuchin winked at him and made a motion like cutting a steak. “You do it yet?” it asked.

“Do what,” Ephraim said. His mouth was dry. He didn’t like its interest. He didn’t like the way news traveled in fur.

“Dinner,” the monkey said. “The city is hungry. Your stomach is a balcony.”

“Stop talking,” said the girl with the calculus book, and the monkey hopped away, offended but pleased with its own offended. The tram sang that song metal sings when it’s tired. The driver didn’t stop at the hospital even when a woman in the aisle clutched her belly and made a sound like a zipper breaking. They said the hospitals were full of monkeys. They said monkeys cradled babies and did not drop them. They said many things. Ephraim had learned, in the last six months, to write the words they say in his notebook and put a box beside them and leave it unchecked.

He got home at nine. The bakery downstairs had closed. The scent of sugar lingered like a rumor. He leaned against the door and thought about the moment before a storm when the air feels like a wet map, the moment where all the roads lead into the center and also away. He closed his eyes. He saw the word nephew. He saw it without letters. He saw it as a shape: a small shape with too much gravity, a shape that makes everything bend.

He opened his eyes. There was a second note under the door. He did not move. He watched it as if you could make a letter go away by not touching it. His heart did something he didn’t approve of. He bent finally, because that is what men who hold ledgers do, they bend and they lift and they add. He opened the note. He did not breathe while he opened it, as if oxygen were a vote.

It said: Do not share this with anyone. Do not. There is a timeline and we are already late. The monkeys are rehearsal. The bright snow is real. We will all die in it. Eat him, Ephraim. You said you would once. Once you said, If the world asked me, I would. The world is asking. It has written it on its cheek in lipstick. Do the small cruelty to prevent the large. Do the close harm to save the far.

No signature. A smear of something at the bottom that looked like ash but smelled like sugar.

He went to the window. Outside, a troop had stolen a car and were taking turns honking the horn while one sat on the roof and made a speech about freedom that was only curse words and two big ideas. A policeman stood on the corner and watched and smoked and didn’t call it in. A stranger walked past with a guitar case and did not open it. The world had learned how to keep its secrets in plain sight.

He slept on the couch because the bed was haunted by decision. He woke at two to a sound that sounded like monkeys singing a lullaby and a man screaming his own name. He thought about the bright snow—ash, he supposed, an event where burning went wrong—and he looked at the ceiling and tried to make himself into the kind of person who could lift a fork with the wrong thing on it. He failed. He fell asleep imagining he had hung his conscience out the window like laundry, and the monkeys had stolen it, and were throwing it like a frisbee from one building to the other, and he was laughing in a way he never laughed.

Days snowed into one another like paperwork left outside. Lark sent him an email with a link to an article about ancient accountants with knives. Darla told him that a monkey had broken into the copy room and eaten a ream of paper with a relish that had made the interns almost love it. Hart canceled a meeting and rescheduled it and canceled it again. The mayor was on television saying that a little anarchy was just the price of life. Miriam texted him a picture of Rory asleep, face half turned, the blue hair like a lake in winter. He stared at the picture for a long time. He hit the heart. He put the phone on the table and did not pick it up again for a while.

Then the first fire came. It was small and stupid. A macaque playing with a bottle of rubbing alcohol in a barber shop. A match, a flare, a whoop. The hair-curled smoke. The barbers went outside. The monkeys clapped. Someone threw a bucket of water that was not enough. The newspaper ran a picture that was almost beautiful, and in the corner of the picture, a man who looked like Ephraim watched a ceiling tile fall, and you could see his hand had lifted slightly, as if a reflex might catch a burning square of artificial sky, as if catching were a promise. The caption read: Barber Fire One of Many Small Incidents. The paper liked to end sentences with a verb. It told you nothing was finished.

At Kettle & Hart, Ephraim’s spreadsheet grew a new column: costs of burns, costs of smoke, costs of night. He colored it black. He sent it to the mayor. The mayor’s assistant wrote back a string of emojis the meaning of which was: send fewer graphs and also die.

On Thursday afternoon, Lark came into his office without knocking and shut the door and cried. He cried with his whole body, like he had been holding something an hour too long. Ephraim stood up and did the thing most people would do, which is put a hand tentatively on someone else’s back and then leave their hand there, a hand as placeholder for all the things you cannot do.

“They told me,” Lark said into the crook of his elbow. “There is an item. A budget. There’s a date. It’s printed. Someone printed it. If you print it, it becomes real. You know that.”

“What is the item,” Ephraim asked, though he knew the tune.

“Uncle’s Tithe,” Lark said. “It’s not metaphor anymore. It’s an appointment.” He laughed, a broken cup sound. “They wrote in the cost: none.” He looked up. His face was wet without shame. “Are we the kind of people who let an appointment keep itself?”

“Apparently,” Ephraim said. “Apparently we are walking toward it like a dentist appointment.”

“You could refuse,” Lark said. “You could. You could go on television. You could be arrested. It’s a kind of math. You could put yourself in prison instead. If they take you, they can’t make you.”
