“There’s another thing,” Hart said, and his voice had put down its lightness like a coat. “If you drown the wrongs and cut the lines and eat the names and shave no one, you still have men with an interest in the Clause. You have one or two who maybe liked the knife because it made the city behave. You have somebody who wrote those sugar letters. They will try to shift the ritual back toward pain because pain is a better anchor for a habit. They will engineer a failure. They will trip a switch. They will pay a boy to push a red button shaped like a toy. They will convince a monkey to light a flame under a thing that reads where it isn’t supposed to. They will say the paper does not taste good anymore.”

“They will try contingency Theta on a Tuesday,” the Cultural Affairs woman said, and looked like a woman ordering a drink she knows will be flat. “They will say there was a leak. They will say the festival kept the trucks from the gate. They will translate physics into malice. We have two weeks, and then their patience will convert to geometry. We need redundancies they can’t undo with a small wickedness.”

“We stage an extra rite,” Lark said. He had unrolled another print without confessing he’d brought it. “Not a show. A village thing. Quiet. The old accountants called them attestations. You make a line of people and each holds the ledger and breathes on it. You count the breaths. You mark the breath with ash and oil so the air learns to stick. You take the total to the plant and you give it to the man with the stutter and you say, We breathed this many times for you, and he nods and he feels like a man whose house was circled by the town at night so the wolves would hear footsteps and leave.”

“Breath as component,” the mayor said, and for the first time that day looked like someone who might have been a person before the word mayor had nailed his head to the building. “Breath as a number. We can issue a certificate of breath. We can accept or reject in triplicate. We can make a pile of inhalations a thing you can drive trucks on.”

“Do not issue,” Miriam said. “Do not monetize. Do not let it be a stamp you can buy. Let it be a line in the ledger no one is allowed to round. Let it be done in the alley, at the plant fences, in kitchens, at the Hall, in barber chairs, on buses that still stop, in the cannery dock on the three nights it isn’t trying to be a cathedral. Let no one own it. Let everyone know it happened.”

They argued another hour because argument is how you bind a plan to a city that resists being bound. In the end, they wrote down: paper, ink, bowl, goats, hair wreath, ledger drowning, breath, witnesses, olives. They wrote: no blood, no hair from any human face, no children near the knife even if it is a prop. They wrote: mandate laughter, forbid jeering at the wrong moments, allow singing in two keys, prohibit plastic knives. They wrote: contingency Epsilon—open every bridge manually with men pulling chains if the power goes. They wrote: call the plant every twenty-seven minutes like a man calling a lover who lives alone.

On the way out, in the corridor where the walls carried the hung faces of former financial officers whose eyes had been made of that cheap varnish that makes sorrow waterproof, the mandrill stopped beside Ephraim and watched her reflection in the glass of a framed certificate that had lost its meaning when the city had given new jobs to different sins. “You will stand on the pallet again,” she said. It was not a question and it did not taste like command. “You will let them watch you cut the line. They will mark the angle of your elbow and make it a fashion. They will want to kiss your hand and bite your wrist. You will learn to keep your hands in your pockets.” She leaned closer and he smelled the old fruit on her breath, sweet and wrong. “When they ask you to say the boy’s name, you will say instead the word ledger until it becomes a person, and then you will say the word city until it becomes an animal.”

“I am not brave,” he said, which has the advantage of sounding like humility and the disadvantage of being true.

“You are useful,” she said. “Usefulness is a courage cities understand. Also you made something I could eat when all the men wanted was a scream. I am not sure if that makes you priest or cook. Either way, you owe me a napkin.”

On the steps outside, a troop had invented a new sport: eating substitute scrip while doing handstands. A rhesus fell and laughed because pain performed is a kind of currency. The capuchin with the bandaged ear presented itself with a solemnity that had been missing for months and handed him a folded piece of glossy paper with an image on it that had been cut from a magazine. It was an advertisement for a winter festival in a far city where the snow fell the old way. “We don’t like bright snow,” the capuchin said, as if confessing a shame. “It tastes like cleaning. It gets in the fur and makes the babies cough. We like dirty snow that tells you what everyone stepped in. If you do the thing with goats, I will throw rocks at anyone who tries to throw rocks at the goats.”

“Thank you,” Ephraim said, and meant it in the way you mean it when a thing whose teeth scare you offers its teeth to your defense.

The week bent itself into preparations the way wire remembers a shape when you twist it. Rory filmed people breathing on paper for Lark’s attestation archive, and he did it with such a tenderness the air around the subjects seemed to thicken. He cut a tutorial about refusal that moved like a disease and was greeted on phones by faces who had learned to open every link with suspicion. There was a shot of the bowl filling with names he had found in the sewer of the budget; there was a shot of a dog shedding while a hand collected the hair; there was a shot of a goat chewing an invoice with the concentration of a monk; there was a shot of Miriam on her stoop, solemn as a gate, speaking the line We eat the paper and keep the breath as if it were a recipe her mother had taught her at the sink. He watched it back and cut and cut until the film did the thing he had promised: it taught a city a muscle.

Hart secured the goats with a mixture of charm and a check that would bounce only if two more fires happened. Darla acquired the hair wreath with an efficiency that made everyone understand she had been waiting all her life to deliver a relic. She had a cousin in a grooming shop who thought the city was a halting romance with a dog and who took it as a point of pride to build a wreath big enough to shame a doorway. The Cultural Affairs woman wrangled the agency list until every page had a phone number in the upper right corner and a person next to it who would actually pick up. The mayor practiced not saying nephew in a mirror and practiced saying ledger with the gravity of a man saying his own name.

The sugar letters did not stop. One arrived tucked into a loaf at the bakery that had begun to bake at night with the doors open so smell could be a resource. It said, in that careful bookstore hand, You are staining the city with cowardice. It said, Eat the child and be done. It said, We have been told we only need once, and after once history grows a rind and cannot be cut. It smelled like cinnamon, which made the threat feel cozy in a way that would be funny if it were not a rehearsal of doom. Another was slid into the slit of his office door during the hour the monkeys turned the tenth floor into a squeal. It bore only a date and a drawing of a knife that had a shadow. He put both notes in the refrigerator because the cold had become the place where he put ideas that wanted to ripen into wrong.

Two days before the moon’s appointment, there was a test of the breath ritual that went badly in the way practice must sometimes fail to save you later. In an alley behind the plant, a line of men and women and one child who had decided to be brave in her own way held the ledger and breathed and counted and marked a page with ash. A rhesus youth who had joined them the way birds join a flock when it moves toward something interesting took a marker and drew a mustache on the number 8. The child laughed, and the laugh echoed, and the echo sounded like jeering, and the men behind the fence looked up as if someone had thrown a stone. It took ten minutes to untangle the meanings, and when it was done a human woman and a monkey child cried for the same length of time without looking at each other, and someone said it was a rehearsal and someone else said it was a warning, and Lark wrote in a notebook with pleasure because his profession records pain with a gratitude that sometimes embarrasses him into softness.

On the eve, the city staged a different kind of riot: a rumor that the goats had escaped and were eating the flower beds in front of the municipal court. It was true in the way things are true when goats stand where men are used to standing and look more dignified than any argument. The court custodians came out and offered them salt on their palms like sacrifices to a myth that lacked a theologian. A troop of macaques in high-visibility vests set up sawhorses around the flower beds as if the goats were a crucial repair. People applauded. A man in a business suit tried to lecture a goat on the dangers of symbolism and the goat turned its head and sneezed spinach on his shoes. The mandrill watched from a step and looked pleased in a way that made It impossible to tell if she was approving of goats or of the ease with which animals made human fidelity look silly.

That night, a transformer somewhere that had been waiting to defend its honor finally chose to die. The neighborhoods flickered in a pattern that suggested a man’s heart in an arrhythmia. In the short dark, a fight broke out under the viaduct where a man was sure his car had been blessed by an invisible authority to ignore certain lines. The monkeys yelled and then mediated and then yelled again. At the cannery, the pallets stood blank in the light of portable floodlamps, which looked like moons mounted on tripods and turned to face an audience that had not arrived. The Cultural Affairs woman walked the perimeter, counting under her breath as if a word repeated often enough can become an obstacle you can place in front of catastrophe.

He slept lightly, because the city had trained him to wake when verbs happen. When the hour came—the mean hour, the one that had enjoyed a reputation in older stories—he put on his jacket and his shirtsleeves did not quarrel with him, and he checked his pockets for the things you bring to a rite: a pen, a small folded photograph he did not let himself look at because he knew exactly what it contained, a list of names printed from the ledger like a tendon from a bone, and a coin from his mother’s jar because she had always believed the world lets you pass if you carry something that understands the value of weight.

Outside, the night had put on its formal shoes. The air carried a smell that could have been frost if the city weren’t too warm at its core for that. Monkeys lined wires. People lined sidewalks. Goats rode in the back of a truck with a patient grace that made Ephraim want to be better at what he had chosen to be. Miriam walked beside him with a basket of olives as if she were a woman in a painting that has always existed. Rory walked backwards, filming and not tripping, and every now and then he blew gently on his lens, as if fog could be dissuaded with polite breath. Hart walked behind with Darla talking him into not kicking a traffic cone that had been placed to look like a hat.

Inside the Hall of Balances, they had made a spectacle out of sobriety. The bowl sat on the table like a mouth that had learned to close. The hair wreath hung on the door, ridiculous and perfect. The ledger rested on a stand that had been built by Public Works out of old stair treads so that it felt like a book that had done labor all its life. The mayor stood with his hand already on the pen as if he were ready to sign away the whole city if someone told him a good story. The mandrill perched on a chair and did not resemble a human and therefore looked more like one.

The juvenile rhesus announced himself by tripping and recovering in a way that made everyone who had ever had a body feel for him, and then he puffed his chest because it is the right of the young to believe in their faces. The chimp went to a window and stared at his own dark reflection and put a hand to the glass where his chest was as if swearing to a god who lives in panes. The Cultural Affairs woman did a headcount and used a pencil to write yes next to everything that would later be rewritten as no.

Ephraim stepped to the pallet they had brought in because the city now loved a stage. He set the ledger on its stand, and he felt the book’s spine with his palm the way men touch animals to comfort them. The first page he opened to was an old one, a page that had survived damp and hands. It carried a number he knew by its posture. He cut the line with the municipal knife, which had the decency to be dull, and he laid the thin strip of white into the bowl, and it landed like a small fall forgiven. He did not say nephew. He said ledger once, then ledger again, then ledger until the word lost its meaning and became a sound like wood in a wind. The mandrill watched and did not blink until he had laid three strips and then she looked up and out the window as if to be sure no bright snow was falling from a sky that had never promised to behave.

They cut and they laid and they breathed. They took the breath into the book the way a poor man takes food into the house by standing outside and thinking hard about soup. They passed the ledger to the mayor and he breathed and failed to look ridiculous, which is the hardest thing a mayor does. They passed it to the rhesus and he breathed and made it a game and then took the game seriously, and when he handed it to the chimp the chimp held it with two hands and breathed a breath that shook the stand. Lark stood to the side and made the notes a scholar makes when he knows his book will be footnoted by the hungry.

When the bowl was heavy enough that the table creaked, they lifted it together and carried it to the door. The hair wreath brushed Ephraim’s shoulder and left against his jacket a softness that would stay past washing. Outside, the goats stamped, impatient in the dignity of animals you have asked to symbolize. The crowd parted. The monkeys in the trees quieted with the concentration of children learning a bad word they intend to deploy sparingly. They carried the bowl down the steps and out toward the river, and every few feet someone put their hand to the bowl’s lip as if to steady it or to bless it. A rhesus leapt down and licked the rim, and a woman in a coat that had belonged to her mother slapped his hand away and then let him hold her shoulder for balance as he smiled at being told no.

At the river, in the place where the cannery had learned to resemble a Cathedral and then learned to suppose it might be a warehouse again, they set the bowl on the wall and lifted. The paper slid in a single gelatinous mass and hit the water with a sound like many small pages agreeing to let go. The current took it and did not choke. The goats, whose owner had insisted on being called by his first name as if goats were above titles, stepped forward with ceremony and chewed the strips that had stuck to the rim with a focus that made the whole act look like a psalm. People cried in the way of men who have decided crying is the tax for still being here.

After the bowl, there were names to eat and names to drown and names to refuse. He looked once at the list and saw his own printed in a column that was not meant for eating, and for a second his body thought it would have to learn a new verb. He put his finger on his name and then put the page face down. When the bowl was empty and the water had carried its lint upriver to the place where sewage is turned into something less insulting, someone began to sing the paper chant. Someone else sang a different song, about something that happened in a valley far away. The songs braided and did not quarrel.

It was almost too smooth. He knew enough about the city to distrust clean. The smooth broke at the edge of the crowd where a boy with a face that would someday be a man’s wore a hooded sweatshirt with the hood up in a way that made his mother invisible. He lifted a bottle from his sleeve with the shame of someone who had been asked to be a knife and wanted to prove he could cut in public. The capuchin with the bandage saw him first because the world owed him that moment. The monkey moved like the small version of mercy and put its hand on the boy’s wrist with a gentleness that made the wrist remember it belonged to someone who had once held a spoon. The boy looked down and the capuchin looked up and they both looked sideways where a man with a municipal badge had stood on a landing and read a notice. The boy put the bottle back. The capuchin took the boy’s hood and pulled it off, which is the monkey way of shaving a head. The crowd put out the breath it had been holding and then took another.

When it was over, the Cultural Affairs woman adjusted the note she had written to herself about the timing of goats. The mayor went home and sat on the edge of his bed and looked at his feet until the alarm clock, which had been set because the city requires a man with a title to observe the morning, told him to stand. Lark went back to his office and laid his hands on the bone stick and felt for a splinter and found none. Hart went to a bar that had become a room where guilt performed itself on ice and told a joke that made three men swear they would stop hating him and then left without saying goodnight because some kinds of happiness must be managed alone. Rory went home with his mother and cut a version of the night that did not have Ephraim in it at all and sent it to a list of addresses with the subject line Watch This To Learn A Mouth. Miriam lay on her bed and cried without letting her throat make a sound because some sounds are owed to different days. The mandrill slept on a roof curled around a heat vent like a poor god and dreamed of a river that speaks.

Ephraim counted. He counted trucks. He counted the breaths that had been taken and were now scattered in lungs and along the river, in the goats’ bellies, in the bowl with its rim salt-bitter on the tongue. He counted the futures he had bought and the ones he had not yet been asked to save. He counted the days until a fortnight. He counted the letters in the word components and the letters in the word breath and tried to accept that they were not the same and never would be. He put his head on his ledger and listened for a heartbeat and found a rustle that could be paper or could be a small animal settling. He closed his eyes because morning had declared itself and because men like him do not sleep; they adjourn.

The morning came with the small cruelty of details. The plant reported the gauges in the green and the engineer with the stutter sent a message that said Thank and then stopped because the word you is heavy and he had no one to lift it to. The Ritual Advisory Council issued a statement denying it existed and praising the goats for their service to public morale. The paper ran a headline that had been designed the day before and tweaked at dawn: Ledger Drowned; City Breathes. The SENSEFUL STREETS group put out a poster with a goat drawn badly and a speech bubble that said Accounting Is For Carnivores. A troupe of spider monkeys demonstrated, under a traffic light that had given up, how to cut paper without cutting fingers and the fifth monkey bled anyway and laughed because the city required it.

At noon, the sugar letter arrived not at his apartment, not at the office, but in the hands of the capuchin on the tram. The monkey did not joke. It put the paper into Ephraim’s hand with a dead seriousness that felt like a ceremony. He unfolded it because you cannot refuse an oar when you are in water. The hand was the same careful hand, the ink the same cheap kind. It said, in a smaller, more cramped line, We are not satisfied with paper and goats. This is large arithmetic. The thing in the south is greedy. The bright snow is a clause you do not control. In fourteen nights, the winter comes if the appetite is not met. It smelled not of sugar but of ash, and the ash tasted, when he licked his finger and touched it, like the inside of a matchbook.

“What do we do,” the capuchin asked, as if it were begging him to say something human. “Who do we bite if biting does not fix the sky.”

“We buy more time,” he said, because a man in his job ends every sentence that way. “We do not let them put a mouth on the wrong thing. We keep the bridges open. We breathe until the numbers change. We ask the river to help and we give it everything we have that is not a boy.”

“Numbers are bones,” the capuchin said solemnly, as if remembering something he had learned from a woman with a scarf and a boy with blue hair. “We can throw bones to dogs and the dogs will be happy. We cannot throw bones to winter. Winter wants houses.”

He nodded. The tram swayed. The girl with the calculus book underlined something with a pencil that had lost its eraser and then looked out the window at a sign where someone had painted over the word STOP with the words KEEP BREATHING. He wrote the last line of the sugar letter into his pocket ledger because you must write down the words that try to command you so that they are subject to a list. He closed the book and put his hand over it like a lid because some days you give your stomach a little win and pretend it is a strategy.

That night, when he unlocked his door, there was a smell he could not place. It was not gas, it was not bread, it was not the candle from a woman who wielded theater like a wrench. It was a sweetness that had gone bad without spoiling. He followed it down the hall and found the refrigerator ajar. Inside, where he had been keeping the notes chilled like fish you swear you will not cook, there was no paper. There was a hole in the frost where paper edges had been. There was a single olive he had not put there. He touched the olive with his forefinger. It had a bite gone from it. On the inside of the refrigerator door, someone had drawn a mouth with a marker in the wrong hand. The mouth had a tongue. The tongue extended, as jokes sometimes do, too far. He shut the door and the bulb went dark and he stood with his hand on the handle and decided, again, that he would not decide today. He would decide tomorrow, which is to say he would have to decide tonight in secret and hope morning would be fooled.

On his chair, someone had left a book. It was the old kind, the smell of a basement and a church and a stack of winter sweaters. The title had rubbed off except for the word Accounts. Inside, on the first page, in a grandmother hand, a sentence: If we must count, we will count with our mouths closed. He sat with it and the night annoyed the window and somewhere a monkey laughed and somewhere a man wept and somewhere a machine thought it would be a beautiful thing to break. He closed his own mouth and held his breath until his chest said please and then he let it out slowly and wrote the number one on the blank next page without ink. He pressed so hard the paper dented, which is one way a city survives.

Chapter 10

He woke in the thin light to the smell the refrigerator had left behind, a sweetness turned cynical, and opened the door as if he might catch the culprit before it had a chance to choose a different home. The notes were gone, the olive with the bite still sat in its ridiculous solitude, and the drawn mouth on the inside door looked smug in the way that only ink can look when it thinks it has made a point. He wiped the marker mouth away with the rough side of a sponge and thought of the phrase clean slate and how it never once in his life had meant clean. He made coffee the way a man fortifies himself for a conversation he cannot win, pressed his thumb into the dent he had written on his own page the night before, and felt how the paper fought back gently, not a refusal so much as a reminder that even fibrous things have a spine.

Hart let himself into the office without knocking, which had become his way of loving people in a crisis, and stood by the window with his tie looped once and then given up on, as if it were a sentence that had found it had said enough. “We have twelve days,” he said without preface, as if they were both mid-prayer and had forgotten to fold their hands. “We have trucks that think they are shy and a plant that wants lullabies and a Council that has translated appetite into font size. We have bridges that remember what men with chains were for.” He slapped a paper on the desk that had been printed with a municipal seriousness that tried to make itself appear inevitable. “Epsilon, manual. Darla blessed it with her highlighter. She found you the names of the men who still teach chains to listen. They keep the keys in a locker labeled ‘Mascots’ because the city is embarrassed by muscle.”

The GIS analyst called on a channel so quiet it sounded as if she were phoning through cloth. “I taught the map a new word,” she said. “Theta. The overlay insists on turning the vanishing tooth into a mouth again on nights when our power lines dream of their childhood. 999 Cherry’s ghost is back, not as a building but as a route. The overlay says Bright Bridges Temporary will run a convoy through the cannery at the hour of doubt. They renamed the truck icon ‘festival.’ It’s a whim and a lie and a plan.” She mailed him the picture and he watched the gray block ghost in and out, learned its rhythm, counted the intervals the way a woman counts contractions when she wants time to behave.

Lark arrived with a rabbit-warren of rolled paper and the bone tally like a wand he had refused a job in a children’s movie to keep. He set the maps on the desk and weighed their corners with staplers because scholars are the only men left who have weights handy. “Attestations moved out of the churchy spaces,” he said with a cheer he refused to name grief. “We’ve got breath on paper from nine wards and a stray from the airport. Teens are breathing on the backs of their math homework because they like the wrongness. They’re turning the breath page over to see the ghost of their equations and they think that’s magic. It is, a little. Rory’s piece taught them a mouth. They are doing it without the music sometimes and sometimes with, and the monkeys are watching and trying the count on their fingers and pretending they don’t care when the number five licks their brain.” He held up a page dented with a hundred patient exhales and said very softly, to himself, “That ought to be worth a chain.”

At the plant the engineer with the stutter met him with a spoon he had wrapped in a paper towel as if it were an heirloom. “They put gum on the valve,” he said, the g of gum heavy, and Ephraim thought of boys in alleys and wives with black aprons and monkeys with nothing to do and all of the city’s fingers pressed into mistakes. “I don’t know who. I don’t ask. I scraped it with this. My mother said never throw away a spoon that fits your hand. I might be arrested for saying it, but I want you to have it.” The spoon’s bowl had a notch worn by soup and by time. It felt like a tongue trying to make a number better by tasting it. He slid it into his jacket pocket with a care that was not for metal but for the stories that choose to hitch a ride there.

The Cultural Affairs woman asked for a walk by the river and did not light a candle. “Be practical,” she said, and then laughed at herself because she sounded like a person who sells pillows. “My deputy—June—put ash on the notes with a finger she dipped in an old tin I keep on my desk for emergencies and ghosts. She wrote them on my paper with my pen and wept about you in the bathroom because she was ashamed of doing the thing she thought would save the city. She is not a villain. She is an employee with a daughter named May, and the world told her that if you do not make the ritual strong you get winter for dessert.” The apology sat between them like a dog that had learned it was allowed on furniture now. “I removed her from the line where words turn to summonses,” she added. “I did not fire her because the city might need later the kind of woman who can smell when the floor is going to give.”

“What does Theta buy,” he asked. He watched a cormorant go under as if it had seen a ledger in the water it needed to balance.

“Leverage,” she said, adjusting her scarf as if she could arrange her soul with wool. “Insurers hold it. A contractor whose trucks have cherries on them holds it. A lobbyist who can make the word contingency sound like a meal holds it. Theta is a club over our head. Every hour we buy by making a meal out of paper, they will try to sell back to us at markup. We’re paying an interest rate in fear. The clause isn’t a law. It’s a mood at a conference table. I’m saying this out loud because we are running out of time to tell the truth in full sentences.”

He went to Miriam for the part of this kind of day where you allow something to be obvious in front of someone who won’t sell it. She had pulled the curtains half-closed so the apartment looked like a memory of itself. “Irreversible,” she said, serving him a pear on a plate that had belonged to their grandmother so old it had wood in it. “The mandrill asked for something we can’t walk back. I thought of shaving my head and decided I’m not sentimental about hair in that direction. I thought of taking the sign off the countinghouse and writing museum in chalk so it could be erased. I thought of writing uncle on the ground outside the Hall and rubbing it out with my heel until the word cried. Then I thought of olive pits, which do a sneaky thing with permanence. You eat the olive. You spit the pit. The pit lingers on the ground making promises. I want to make a pit with the city. Something we plant.” She stabbed the pear with her knife in a way that made the pear feel like victory and then pulled back because she saw his face. “We could shut a lane that leads to the cannery forever and make it a strip of garden,” she said more gently. “A literal barrier between the pallets and the street. They can’t drive vans through a trellis if the trellis holds beans.”

The mandrill held court on a library roof, because monkeys choose their rooms by the quality of ledges, and listened to her cousins’ arguments with a kind of patient boredom that told you she had learned more than you thought from watching committees. The juvenile rhesus, feeling the moon fatten whether or not he believed in it, insisted on eyebrows again with an affection that made his rudeness almost lovely. The chimp rapped his knuckles on the skylight and stared into the reading room where three humans had fallen asleep with newspapers on their faces, and the mandrill said in her old-longshoreman voice that hair wreaths hung at every door would satisfy the old ones for a season if they smelled like dog and if the wreaths were taken to the river after. She said, too, that if anyone cut a girl’s hair without asking, she would bite them on the hand so that the scar would be a reason forever not to do it again. The rhesus nodded solemnly like a page accepting a task, and then, being fifteen in spirit, attempted to steal a bookmark from a man below and failed twice and then succeeded once and felt the holy thrill of trivial theft.

They built a list and then they built a practice. Darla printed, stamped, collated, and put her lipstick on with a steadiness that made all the red in the city look like a promise and not a threat. She made “breath cards” that were not cards, just paper heavy enough to take a fingernail, and the fingernail left a clear mark that no one could erase without cutting the page. She assigned runners to the bridges and scheduled calls as if scheduling were prayer. Hart found the goat man leaning on a fence talking softly to an animal who did not need human words and made him promise three times that he would accept apples and not ask for changes in the law as payment. The goat man, whose name was Salim and who owned two pairs of socks that had learned to love mud, agreed to bring the cleanest, hungriest mouths in the city to the Hall for a second contract of silence.

The night sent an emissary to him in the form of a woman sitting on the cannery steps with her shoes off and her stockings rolled around her ankles like two different regrets. June, the deputy, did not stand when he stopped. She offered him a cigarette she did not light as if she were making a joke for a movie that liked to show competence as ruin. “I’m not sorry enough,” she said plainly. “I wrote the notes because in every meeting I sat in men made euphemisms until I wanted to drag my face on carpet. I thought if I put the fear in pretty, you’d obey the pretty. It worked and it didn’t. It always works and it never does. I’m fired in the way that keeps my health insurance, which is how this city breaks your heart without technically doing anything wrong.” She lifted her head. “Theta isn’t just a clause. It’s a specific mischief. There are three warehouses with tanks that would behave like a bad winter if they were convinced it was their time. Two are guarded. One is watched by a man who plays cards with our enemies. He’s not a villain either. He’s lonely.” She slid him a list folded so tight he needed his thumbnail to pry it open. “There is so much to guard that we will fail. There is, maybe, just enough to love that the failure will not be the kind that steals breath. Do not forgive me now. I don’t want to write that scene.”

On the last day before the moon did its old theater, the city performed a blasphemous rehearsal. Powder fell from a rooftop along a block in the Ward with the broken clock, tossed from five-gallon buckets by boys who had been promised a hardness by a man on a phone who had never once stood and watched a sky remember how to behave. The powder wreathed the block and tongues found it the way tongues find worry. The monkeys shrieked and then acted sick and then laughed and then were still, which was the strangest part. Hydrants were opened by men who had pulled their whole lives and watched the pretend ash turn to paste that never forgot its baptism. A goat wandered in from a lot and licked the paste with a look of someone willing to try any food once. The powder turned the goat’s chin gray. The goat shook its head, sneezed, and trotted away with an air of disappointment that read like an editorial. The men with the buckets watched their theater melt and did not clap. The Cultural Affairs woman arrived with a mop and the mayor with a rolled-up plan he forgot to unfurl and the mandrill with her jaw tight. “You think snow is cheap,” she said to no one and everyone. “Wait until you have to sweep.” Ephraim wrote in his ledger: practice panic, sweep, kebab for the men who opened the valves, no notes.

Harvest night came dressed as itself. The moon had the confidence of an elder who has outlived everybody’s taste. The Hall of Balances smelled like unwashed wool and ink. The wreath on the door looked foolish until it didn’t. The bowl glared, which is a trick bowls know. The ledger lay open to the part where deceit narrows like a river into usable pain. The goat man stood by with his hand on his favorite’s head, and the favorite looked at him with a devotion so stupid it could save a family from a fire. The bridges waited for chains and hands. Public Works checked the manual cranks with banana fingers in gloves. The monkeys took their places in different trees than last time as if to test the city’s reflexes.

They did not speak the boy’s name. They did not even say boy. The mayor said ledger and saw that nobody flinched and then said ledger again softly as if it were a lullaby his mother might have hummed if the world had been something else. Ephraim cut the lines and laid them in the bowl. Each strip of paper seemed to say please, and he could not tell if the paper begged to be eaten or to be spared the indignity of metaphor. Miriam stood in the back with olives and made a face like a gate that keeps. Lark made the cross of someone else’s religion over the bone tally and told it under his breath that it was doing very well. The mandrill watched and breathed only when the chimp breathed, as if to braid the act into a rope that might hold more than animal.

The powder-droppers, having been humiliated by hydrants, tried again in a subtler place, the roof of the post office where the city hides the letters that hurt. The capuchin who had stolen a stapler days before used it to hit the elbow of the boy about to spill and said, in a tone of casual companionship, “Don’t.” The boy’s face did the quick arithmetic of dignity; he looked at the city, the moon, his own hand, and then he put the bucket down and sat with his legs over the edge so that everyone who looked up had to consider human ankles. It was not heroism. It was posture re-taught.

When the bowl was full enough that the rim tasted like kale, they carried it out. A woman tripped and a man caught her under the elbow and she kissed him without thinking as if luck had to be thanked with mouth. The goats ate the names they were given and let the rest go river. Chains clanked on three bridges and the fourth refused because it had pride and a bad hinge, and four men with hands like history pulled anyway while a troop of rhesus threw their bodies on the chain and felt a pleasure that the city could have used for different things if it had had the time. South, the plant clicked its clicks and the engineer counted, and a figure on a walkway at Warehouse Three, the one with the lonely man, put his phone away and lit a cigarette instead and told himself a story about his daughter in another place and the time he would tell her a story that made him look like a man.

In the Hall someone whispered nephew because there is always a person who insists on touching a hot stove, and the mandrill flicked her ear and a silence fell so sudden it felt like a new weather. The word hung a second and then died the way small fires die when rain picks a neighborhood to love. Hart laughed once under his breath as if he had seen an old joke learn manners. Darla distributed breath cards and told people sternly where to put their nail, and people obeyed because the sternness was full of love and because she had a face the city had agreed not to lie to. The Cultural Affairs woman watched the juvenile rhesus mouth the word ledger and shook like a girl who had rescued a dog from a road and was only now allowed to feel it.

The counter-rite played itself under a streetlight four blocks away, plastic knifery and a poster of a boy borrowed from somewhere that had nothing to do with this city. The crowd did not boo. It turned and walked and the knives fell with the dignity of toys abandoned by toddlers. The men who had brought the knives cried because they had not planned for a script without an ending. Rory filmed them with a gentleness that had edges, and later cut it into the piece that would make people in other cities stop pretending they have no cousins.

After the bowl and the goats and the breath there was a bench. He sat on it because he could feel the shape of himself and it needed a flat thing. The capuchin sat beside him and handed him back the spoon he had forgotten he’d given it, the engineer’s spoon, wrapped again in the paper towel because the monkey had learned etiquette and was proud of knowing where to put its paws. “Your sister’s olives were better tonight,” the capuchin said, and wiped its nose with the back of its hand like a child who has been told twelve times to use a napkin. “I bit two men who said they wanted to do a prank and they agreed they did not. I will not bite as a hobby. I will bite as a craft. Tell your goats they did theater without lying.”

He did not go home because home had the smell of refrigerator regret. He went to the river for a while and watched the skin of the water accept and deny and accept. The moon cupped its light the way a waitress brings coffee. The city made the sound cities make when large things are done and no one died: the kind of cheering you only let the air do for you. The Cultural Affairs woman appeared like a moral at the end of a story told by someone too tired for point and sat without asking if the bench had room. “June left a note,” she said. “No sugar. She wrote in pencil, hard, so it left a valley. It said: I will stop making it worse. It said: If you need me to carry boxes in the rain I can do that and never once choose a noun. I like her again because she is a person. I will tell her daughter that her mother once fed a goat an ugly word and watched it disappear.”

He slept late the next morning and woke to the particular quiet of a city putting itself back on its own lap. The plant’s numbers texted themselves in polite green. The bridges were open, tasting their own usefulness like a metal tongue saying grace. The goat man sent a photo of his animals in a lot under a billboard that used to sell vacations and now just sold sky, their mouths still working with dream. SENSEFUL STREETS put out a poster that corrected its goat and called the rite bourgeois, a word that had lost all meaning in the year and was now just a sound you made when your mouth wanted to feel French. The mayor said in front of microphones that the Rite Advisory Council did not exist and that its meeting was postponed to a date that would be announced when the moon had learned to mind its own business.

At Kettle & Hart, the monkeys had braided ribbons out of the substitute scrip and were using them to try to tow a chair across the floor. Darla put a hand to her mouth as if to hide a spell and then declared loudly that if anyone put their teeth on her copier she would put their head in a file drawer, and four rhesus mimed decapitation and then apologized without being asked. Hart had drawn a goat on his whiteboard and given it a speech bubble that said Pay Your Debts to Rivers. He stood with his shoes off again and said, “You stole time and fed it to something that forgot to be angry at you. That’s a trick. Don’t do it again unless you have to.”

On the tram a woman read a story to a boy with a winter hat in a month that had no right to need hats yet. He watched her mouth shape ledger with more care than he would have thought a stranger had for his private nouns. The capuchin slept, head on his shoe, like a dog with nothing to prove. When he reached his door there was no letter. He opened the refrigerator anyway and there, where the notes had been, was a bowl of olives wrapped in waxed paper with a note in Miriam’s hand that said: You still have a mouth. He stood a long time with the door open tasting the cold and the brine and the possibility that abstaining had bought him something more than just a few hours of trucks. He shut the door not with triumph but with the carefulness of a man who knows he will be asked again and wants to be ready to be the same man twice if he can manage it. He took out his ledger and, with the spoon’s bowl held to the page like a tracer, impressed, with no ink at all, a second number beside the first, and then a third, because sometimes the only way to teach your hands a mercy is to let them count how many times they have chosen not to be knives.
